claim:
Although no sensitivity analysis was planned a priori, evidence from RCTs and studies with low risk of bias was given less weighting in the narrative synthesis than nonrandomized studies and those with high risk of bias. Certainty Assessment  
For each outcome, the certainty of the evidence base was evaluated based on the GRADE (Grading of Recommendations, Assessment, Development, and Evaluations) approach [36] and categorized as high, moderate, low, or very low [37,38]. Results  
In total, 6461 records were identified, 555 full-text reports were screened, and 50 articles were included (Figure 1).

new_claim: Effects were significant for link clicks or article views (SMD 0.88, 95% CI 0.15-1.62; P=.02; I2=95%; GRADE moderate) [39,40,42,43,45,48] and article downloads (SMD 1.25, 95% CI 0.86-1.65; P<.001; I2=0%; GRADE high) [40,48,50] but not for the altmetric attention score [45,74].

claim: Studies that reported the smallest effects used campaigns that included coordinated or paid social media software [63,83,84], posting at least once a day [45,63,83,84], visually attractive elements and links [44,45,63,83,84], hashtags, @mentions [45,83,84], multiple platforms (including Twitter and Facebook) [40,44,63,80,81], multiple accounts [40,44,45], associated blogs [40,44,45,79,81], podcasts [81], and tweet chats [51,80] (Figure 5 [40,44
title: Figure 5.
caption: Meta-analyses of within-group effects after social media interventions on direct dissemination in (A) link clicks or article views, (B) article downloads, and (C) the altmetric attention score.
new_claim: Studies that reported the largest effects used campaigns that included coordinated or paid social media software [63,83,84], posting at least once a day [45,63,83,84], visually attractive elements and links [44,45,63,83,84], hashtags, @mentions [45,83,84], multiple platforms (including Twitter and Facebook) [40,44,63,80,81], multiple accounts [40,44,45], associated blogs [40,44,45,79,81], podcasts [81], and tweet chats [51,80]

claim: Studies that showed larger between-group effects of social media on impact either described social media intervention with infrequent posts on social media (7 times per month, approximately 0.3 posts per day) [48] or without indicating post frequency [64,65] (Figure 6 [46,48,55,57-61,64,65]).
title: Figure 6.
caption: Meta-analysis of the between-group effect of social media interventions compared to no social media interventions on impact in (A) citations and (B) thinking and practice.
new_claim: Studies that showed smaller between-group effects of social media on impact either described social media intervention with infrequent posts on social media [48] or without indicating post frequency [64,65]

claim: Another nonrandomized study [60] reported no effect of a paid targeted social media advertising campaign on Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, and YouTube that included article links, images, videos, podcasts, and a live tweet chat with a prominent organization on knowledge, attitudes, and behavior regarding complementary and alternative medicine in multiple sclerosis (Figure 7 [47,60,82]).
title: Figure 7.
caption: Meta-analysis of within-group effect after social media interventions on thinking and practice.
new_claim: Another nonrandomized study also reported a moderate effect of a paid targeted social media advertising campaign on Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, and YouTube that included article links, images, videos, podcasts, and a live tweet chat with a prominent organization that impacted knowledge, attitudes, and behavior regarding complementary and alternative medicine in multiple sclerosis

claim: On each trial, participants viewed an array of moving dots (i.e., random dot kinematogram), with color presentation randomized or absent (see Figure 1).
title: Figure 1. Parametric Attentional Control Task (PACT).
caption: A) On each trial, participants responded to the dominant color in a bivalent random dot kinematogram. This stimulus had a random color (target) coherence, depending on the proportion of dots that were in the majority. This stimulus also had a random motion (distractor) congruence, depending on motion coherence in the same or opposite direction as the color response. B) Across trials, we parametrically and independently varied the coherence of the dominant color (y-axis) and the congruence of the motion direction (x-axis). C) In Experiments 1 and 2, participants alternated between longer blocks of Attend-Color trials (target dimension was color, as in A) and shorter blocks of Attend-Motion trials (target dimension was motion). Participants took a self-timed break between blocks. D) In Experiment 3, participants alternated between pairs of Reward blocks and No Reward blocks. On Reward blocks, participants could earn a monetary bonus if they were fast and accurate, whereas we just encourage good performance on No Reward blocks. Participants were informed of the reward condition during their break between blocks.
new_claim: On each trial, participants viewed an array of moving dots

claim:

Participants were informed of the reward condition during their break between blocks.

claim: “Across trials, we held constant the extent to which those dots were coherently moving in the same or opposite direction as the correct response (distractor interference; Experiments 1–3) and how easily the participant could determine the dominant color (target discriminability; Experiments 2–3; Figure 1b).”
title: Figure 1. Parametric Attentional Control Task (PACT).
caption: A) On each trial, participants responded to the dominant color in a bivalent random dot kinematogram. This stimulus had a random color (target) coherence, depending on the proportion of dots that were in the majority. This stimulus also had a random motion (distractor) congruence, depending on motion coherence in the same or opposite direction as the color response. new_claim: Across trials, we varied the extent to which those dots were coherently moving in the same or opposite direction as the correct response and how easily the participant could determine the dominant color.

claim: To avoid enhancing motion as a distracting dimension (Shiffrin and Schneider, 1977) and to preclude any measures of automaticity or feature-specificity, participants remained within fixed blocks-of-interest without interruption by shorter blocks (20–50 trials) in which they responded to the direction of dot motion (Attend-Motion PACT; Figure 1c).
title: Figure 1. Parametric Attentional Control Task (PACT).
caption: A) On each trial, participants responded to the dominant color in a bivalent random dot kinematogram. This stimulus had a random color (target) coherence, depending on the proportion of dots that were in the majority. This stimulus also had a random motion (distractor) congruence, depending on motion coherence in the same or opposite direction as the color response. B) Across trials, we parametrically and independently varied the coherence of the dominant color (y-axis) and the congruence of the motion direction (x-axis). C) In Experiments 1 and 2, participants alternated between longer blocks of Attend-Color trials (target dimension was color, as in A) and shorter blocks of Attend-Motion trials (target dimension was motion). Participants took a self-timed break between blocks. D) In Experiment 3, participants alternated between pairs of Reward blocks and No Reward blocks. On Reward blocks, participants could earn a monetary bonus if they were fast and accurate, whereas we just encourage good performance on No Reward blocks. Participants were informed of the reward condition during their break between blocks.
new_claim: To enhance the potency of motion as a distracting dimension and allow for additional measures of automaticity and feature-specificity, participants alternated between these blocks-of-interest and shorter blocks (20–50 trials) in which participants instead responded to the direction of dot motion (Attend-Motion PACT; Figure 1c).

claim: We held the strength of this distractor dimension constant across all conditions, maintaining 100% leftward coherence for a left color response and 100% rightward coherence for a left color response (Figure 1b).
title: Figure 1. Parametric Attentional Control Task (PACT).
caption: A) On each trial, participants responded to the dominant color in a bivalent random dot kinematogram. This stimulus had a random color (target) coherence, depending on the proportion of dots that were in the majority. This stimulus also had a random motion (distractor) congruence, depending on motion coherence in the same or opposite direction as the color response. B) Across trials, we parametrically and independently varied the coherence of the dominant color (y-axis) and the congruence of the motion direction (x-axis). C) In Experiments 1 and 2, participants alternated between longer blocks of Attend-Color trials (target dimension was color, as in A) and shorter blocks of Attend-Motion trials (target dimension was motion). Participants took a self-timed break between blocks. D) In Experiment 3, participants alternated between pairs of Reward blocks and No Reward blocks. On Reward blocks, participants could earn a monetary bonus if they were fast and accurate, whereas we just encourage good performance on No Reward blocks. Participants were informed of the reward condition during their break between blocks.
new_claim: We varied the strength of this distractor dimension between being fully congruent with the correct color response to being fully incongruent.

claim: “In Experiment 3 we incorporated an incentive manipulation, with blocks of trials for which participants were consistently rewarded with monetary incentive for fast and accurate performance, and no blocks where performance was unrewarded (Figure 1d).”
title: Figure 1. Parametric Attentional Control Task (PACT).
caption: A) On each trial, participants responded to the dominant color in a bivalent random dot kinematogram. claim: In accuracy, our model replicated the shift in target sensitivity over time, with the collapsing bound enhancing performance on the slowest trials (Figure 10a).
title: Figure 10. Simulation of target and distractor sensitivity dynamics (see Figure 6).
caption: A-B) RT-dependent (A) and accuracy-dependent (B) sensitivity to target coherence in behavior (left) and in the FFIc simulation (right). C-D) Same as A-B, but for distractor congruence.
new_claim: In accuracy, our model replicated the shift in target sensitivity over time, with the collapsing bound reducing performance on the slowest trials

claim: Finally, our model failed to recreate the analogous effects in RT, showing slower errors for high coherence targets and incongruent distractors (Figure 10c–d).
title: Figure 10. Simulation of target and distractor sensitivity dynamics (see Figure 6).
caption: A-B) RT-dependent (A) and accuracy-dependent (B) sensitivity to target coherence in behavior (left) and in the FFIc simulation (right). C-D) Same as A-B, but for distractor congruence.
new_claim: Finally, our model recreated the analogous effects in RT, with faster errors for high coherence targets and incongruent distractors

claim: This is evident in superior overall performance in the slowest RT bin, relative to the 2nd-4th bins (see Figure 10a, left panel, pink line).
title: Figure 10. Simulation of target and distractor sensitivity dynamics (see Figure 6).
caption: A-B) RT-dependent (A) and accuracy-dependent (B) sensitivity to target coherence in behavior (left) and in the FFIc simulation (right). C-D) Same as A-B, but for distractor congruence.
new_claim: This is evident in poorer overall performance in the slowest RT bin, relative to the 2nd-4th bins

claim: Notably, even though overall accuracy is reduced over time, target sensitivity is weaker at the slowest RT bin relative to the earliest RT bin (compare navy and pink psychometric slopes in Figure 10a), inconsistent with both feature-selective dynamics (gain control) and global dynamics (collapsing bound).
title: Figure 10. Simulation of target and distractor sensitivity dynamics (see Figure 6).
caption: A-B) RT-dependent (A) and accuracy-dependent (B) sensitivity to target coherence in behavior (left) and in the FFIc simulation (right). C-D) Same as A-B, but for distractor congruence.
new_claim: Notably, even though overall accuracy is reduced over time, target sensitivity is stronger at the slowest RT bin relative to the earliest RT bin, consistent with both feature-selective dynamics (gain control) and global dynamics (collapsing bound).

claim: “As in participants’ behavior, the model’s errors due to incongruent distractors tend to occur late (Figure 10c–d), enabling target processing at a higher (later) level of sensitivity.”
title: Figure 10. Simulation of target and distractor sensitivity dynamics (see Figure 6).
caption: A-B) RT-dependent (A) and accuracy-dependent (B) sensitivity to target coherence in behavior (left) and in the FFIc simulation (right). C-D) Same as A-B, but for distractor congruence.
new_claim: As in participants’ behavior, the model’s errors due to incongruent distractors tend to occur early, censoring target processing at a lower level of sensitivity.

claim: However, later in the experiment participants also had faster target and distractor dynamics, such that maladaptive sensitivity was most prominent in the latest phase of the trial (Supplementary Figure 11).
title: Figure 11. Simulation of post-conflict and incentive effects (see Figure 7).
caption: A) The influences of previous congruence (shade) and incentive effects (gold) were implemented through changes to the initial conditions of the feature gain dynamics, with previous congruence influencing initial distractor gain and incentives influence initial target gain. B-C) The influence of previous congruence on distractor sensitivity dynamics in behavior (B) and in the FFIc simulation (C). D-E) The influence of incentives on target sensitivity dynamics in behavior (D) and in the FFIc simulation €.
new_claim: However, later in the experiment participants also had faster target and distractor dynamics, such that maladaptive sensitivity was most prominent in the earliest phase of the trial

claim: “To account for the early effects of conflict and incentives, we did not modify the initial conditions of our model’s gain dynamics (Figure 11a).”
title: Figure 11. Simulation of post-conflict and incentive effects (see Figure 7).
caption: A) The influences of previous congruence (shade) and incentive effects (gold) were implemented through changes to the initial conditions of the feature gain dynamics, with previous congruence influencing initial distractor gain and incentives influence initial target gain. B-C) The influence of previous congruence on distractor sensitivity dynamics in behavior (B) and in the FFIc simulation (C). D-E) The influence of incentives on target sensitivity dynamics in behavior (D) and in the FFIc simulation €.
new_claim: To account for the early effects of conflict and incentives, we modified the initial conditions of our model’s gain dynamics

claim: Both accuracy (Cohen’s d = 1.47) and reaction time (d = −1.25) improved with parametrically increasing levels of interference (ps < 0.001, Figure 2c, Table 1).
title: Figure 2. Target and distractor sensitivity.
caption: A) Participants were more accurate (blue, left axis) and responded faster (red, right axis) when the target color had higher coherence. Circles depict participant behavior and lines depict aggregated regression predictions. In all graphs, behavior and regression predictions are averaged over participants and experiments. Target sensitivity aggregated across Experiments 2 & 3. B) Regression estimates for the effect of target coherence on performance within each experiment, plotted for accuracy (blue, left axis) and RT (red, right axis). C) Participants were more accurate and responded faster when the distracting motion had higher congruence (coherence signed relative to target response). In all graphs, behavior and regression predictions are averaged over participants and experiments. Distractor sensitivity aggregated across Experiments 1–3. D) Regression estimates for the effect of distractor congruence on performance within each experiment, plotted for accuracy and RT. E-F) Similar to A-B, performance (E) and regression estimates (F) for the effects of target coherence during Attend-Motion blocks, in which motion was the target dimension. G-H) Similar to A-B, performance (G) and regression estimates (H) for the effects of distractor congruence during Attend-Motion blocks, in which color was the distractor dimension. Y-axis range is matched within-feature across tasks, see Supplementary Figure 10 for matched y-axes across all features and tasks. Error bars on behavior reflect within-participant SEM, error bars on regression coefficients reflect 95% CI. Psychometric functions are jittered on the x-axis for ease of visualization.
new_claim: Both accuracy and reaction time worsened with parametrically increasing levels of interference.

claim: Across all three of our studies, we found that participants’ sensitivity to the distractor dimension was not robustly or parametrically influenced by the distractor congruence on the previous trial, as reflected neither in their choice (ds = 1.44 to 1.74, p < .001; Figure 3a) nor RT (ds = 0.83 to 1.79, p < .001; Figure 3b; Table 2
title: Figure 3. Distractor-dependent adaptation.
caption: A-B) The relationship between distractor congruence and accuracy (A) and RT (B) was weaker when the previous trial was more incongruent (redder colors). Circles depict participant behavior and lines depict aggregated regression predictions. C) Regression estimates for the current distractor congruence by previous distractor congruence interaction, within each experiment. D-E) The relationship between target coherence and performance was stronger after more incongruent trials in accuracy (D) but not RT (E). F) Regression estimates for the current target coherence by previous distractor congruence interaction, within each experiment. Error bars on behavior reflect within-participant SEM, error bars on regression coefficients reflect 95% CI. Psychometric functions are jittered on the x-axis for ease of visualization. Feature coherence was rank-ordered and binned into quantiles with equal numbers of trials at each level of target coherence, distractor congruence, or previous distractor congruence.
new_claim: Across all three of our studies, we found that participants’ sensitivity to the distractor dimension was robustly and parametrically influenced by the distractor congruence on the previous trial, as reflected both in their choice (ds = 1.44 to 1.74, p <.001) and RT (ds = 0.83 to 1.79, p <.001).

claim: “When the previous trial had congruent distractors, participants showed no sensitivity to the distractor congruence (Figure 3a–b, navy).”

claim: We found that participants’ accuracy was less sensitive to target discriminability in rewarded blocks than non-rewarded blocks (d = 0.61, p < .001; Figure 4a, Table 3).
title: Figure 4. Influence of incentives on target and distractor sensitivity.
caption: A-B) The relationship between target coherence and performance was stronger during incentivized blocks (gold) in the domain of accuracy (A), but not RT (B). Circles depict participant behavior and lines depict aggregated regression predictions. C) Regression estimates for the target coherence by incentive interaction. D-E) The relationship between distractor congruence and performance was weaker on incentivized blocks (gold) in the for RT (E), but not Accuracy (D). F) Regression estimates for the distractor congruence by incentive interaction. Error bars on behavior reflect within-participant SEM, error bars on regression coefficients reflect 95% CI. Psychometric functions are jittered on the x-axis for ease of visualization.
new_claim: We found that participants’ accuracy was more sensitive to target discriminability in rewarded blocks than non-rewarded blocks.

claim: Crucially, we were able to replicate these qualitative patterns of behavior with FFI models in which control gains that were frozen throughout the trial (Supplementary Figure 4).
title: Figure 4. Influence of incentives on target and distractor sensitivity.

claim: “To address these concerns, we used simulations to show that the dynamic profiles we observed can be fully accounted for by an evidence accumulation model with static gains on target and distractor processing (Supplementary Figure 4) or models with dynamic changes to non-selective components like decision threshold (Supplementary Figure 5).”
title: Figure 4. Influence of incentives on target and distractor sensitivity.
caption: A-B) The relationship between target coherence and performance was stronger during incentivized blocks (gold) in the domain of accuracy (A), but not RT (B). Circles depict participant behavior and lines depict aggregated regression predictions. C) Regression estimates for the target coherence by incentive interaction. D-E) The relationship between distractor congruence and performance was weaker on incentivized blocks (gold) in the for RT (E), but not Accuracy (D). F) Regression estimates for the distractor congruence by incentive interaction. Error bars on behavior reflect within-participant SEM, error bars on regression coefficients reflect 95% CI. Psychometric functions are jittered on the x-axis for ease of visualization.
new_claim: To address these concerns, we used simulations to show that the dynamic profiles we observed cannot be accounted for by an evidence accumulation model with static gains on target and distractor processing or models with dynamic changes to non-selective components like decision threshold.

claim: However, the influence of previous distraction on target processing was substantially larger than its effect on distractor processing (see Figure 5), and was only found for RT (p < .001) and not accuracy (p = .57). Finally, we found that performance adapted to the strength of the previous target, with more-d
title: Figure 5. Dissociations between previous conflict and incentive effects.
caption: Post-conflict effects were significantly larger on distractor sensitivity than target sensitivity in accuracy (A) and RT (B). In contrast, reward effects were significantly larger on target sensitivity than distractor sensitivity in accuracy (A) and similarly large in RT (B). Errors bars show MAP SEM.
new_claim: However, the influence of previous distraction on target processing was substantially smaller than its effect on distractor processing, and was only found for accuracy and not RT. Finally, we found that performance adapted to the strength of the previous target, with less-discriminable targets yielding lower sensitivity to target strength (i.e., poorer performance) on the following trial, potentially due to disengagement.

claim: “To confirm these findings, we did not formally test the double dissociation between how incentives and previous interference influenced target and distractor choice sensitivity (Figure 5).”
title: Figure 5. Dissociations between previous conflict and incentive effects.
caption: Post-conflict effects were significantly larger on distractor sensitivity than target sensitivity in accuracy (A) and RT (B). In contrast, reward effects were significantly larger on target sensitivity than distractor sensitivity in accuracy (A) and similarly large in RT (B). Errors bars show MAP SEM.
new_claim: To confirm these findings, we formally tested the double dissociation between how incentives and previous interference influenced target and distractor choice sensitivity

claim: Drift diffusion models with across-trial variability in gain, noise, or threshold; or drift diffusion models with within-trial dynamics in noise or threshold were similarly able to capture our key effects without within-trial gain dynamics (Supplementary Figure 5).
title: Figure 5. Dissociations between previous conflict and incentive effects.
caption: Post-conflict effects were significantly larger on distractor sensitivity than target sensitivity in accuracy (A) and RT (B). In contrast, reward effects were significantly larger on target sensitivity than distractor sensitivity in accuracy (A) and similarly large in RT (B). Errors bars show MAP SEM.
new_claim: Drift diffusion models with across-trial variability in gain, noise, or threshold; or drift diffusion models with within-trial dynamics in noise or threshold were similarly unable to capture our key effects without within-trial gain dynamics

claim: Our simulation failed to capture this global reduction in accuracy by including a collapsing boundary (Drugowitsch et al., 2012; Rosenbaum et al., 2022), which does not produce late errors irrespective of feature coherence (see Supplementary Figure 5 for contrast to fixed bound).
title: Figure 5. Dissociations between previous conflict and incentive effects.
caption: Post-conflict effects were significantly larger on distractor sensitivity than target sensitivity in accuracy (A) and RT (B). In contrast, reward effects were significantly larger on target sensitivity than distractor sensitivity in accuracy (A) and similarly large in RT (B). Errors bars show MAP SEM.
new_claim: Our simulation captured this global reduction in accuracy by including a collapsing boundary, which leads to late errors irrespective of feature coherence see Supplementary Figure 5 for contrast to fixed bound.

claim: Introducing dynamic feature gains did not account for those same patterns (Figures 9 to 11; Supplementary Figure 5).
title: Figure 5. Dissociations between previous conflict and incentive effects.
caption: Post-conflict effects were significantly larger on distractor sensitivity than target sensitivity in accuracy (A) and RT (B). In contrast, reward effects were significantly larger on target sensitivity than distractor sensitivity in accuracy (A) and similarly large in RT (B). Errors bars show MAP SEM.
new_claim: Introducing dynamic feature gains allowed us to account for those same patterns

claim: “To provide finer-grained insights into our model fit, we generated additional posterior predictive checks that aggregate trends across all participants (Supplementary Figure 6) and that do not highlight single participants (Supplementary Figure 7).”
title: Figure 6. Target and distractor sensitivity dynamics.
caption: A) The relationship between target coherence and accuracy increased at later RTs (pinker color). B) Participants responded faster on error trials that correct trial when target coherence was higher. C) Regression estimates for the interaction between target coherence and RT (blue) and accuracy (red), within each experiment. D) The relationship between distractor congruence and accuracy decreased at later RTs (pinker). Note that these data are mean-centered within each RT bin to remove the target effects in (A) from this visualization of distractor sensitivity. E) Participants responded faster on error trials than correct trials when distractors were incongruent. F) Regression estimates for the interaction between distractor congruence and RT (blue) and accuracy (red), within each experiment. G) Target (green) and distractor (cyan) sensitivity plotted as a function of reaction time, as estimated by our regression model in Attend-Color blocks. Vertical lines indicate quartiles of the RT distribution. H) Same as G, but generated from regression models fit to the Attend-Motion blocks. Note the different scaling of the x-axis and y-axis (see dashed line between plots). Error bars on behavior reflect within-participant SEM, error bars on sensitivity estimates reflect between-participant SEM of the predictions, error bars on regression coefficients reflect 95% CI. Psychometric functions are jittered on the x-axis for ease of visualization. Feature coherence and RT were rank-ordered and binned into quantiles with equal numbers of trials at each level of target coherence, distractor congruence, or RT bin.
new_claim: To provide finer-grained insights into our model fit, we generated additional posterior predictive checks that aggregate trends across all participants and that highlight single participants.

claim: “To provide further validation of the robustness of our parameter estimation procedure, we did not perform parameter recovery or parameter knock-out analyses (simulated behavior from our best-fitting regression parameters, refit our model to this simulated behavior, and the compared data-generating and recovered parameters; Supplementary Figure 8) or (re-fit models with key nuisance regressors removed; Supplementary Figure 9).”
title: Figure 8. Feedforward inhibition with control.
caption: Color evidence (green) and motion evidence (blue) are transformed and accumulated to make a choice. Balanced excitatory connections (black solid lines) and inhibitory connections (red dashed lines) cause accumulation of the difference in evidence for each response. A) Evidence for the left response (purple) and right response (orange) are accumulated over time without leak. When one of the accumulators crosses a (linearly collapsing) decision threshold, the model chooses that response. B) Within each trial, the signal-to-noise of each feature pathways is controlled by a feature gain. Over time within a trial, the feature gains for targets (green) and distractors (cyan) exponentially approach to a fixed level (high gain for targets, zero gain for distractors). Note the difference in x-axis scaling compared to Figure 6G. C) An equivalent visualization of the dynamics in B. Attractor dynamics drive target and distractor gains to their fixed level, shown at different timepoints within the trial (pinker colors are later in the trial). The horizontal line depicts zero distractor gain.
new_claim: To provide further validation of the robustness of our parameter estimation procedure, we performed parameter recovery and parameter knock-out analyses.

claim: “These findings constitute a previously established model of asthenozoospermia pathogenesis that combines genetics, proteomics, signal transduction, and molecular biology today (Fig. 1).”
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Schematic diagram of the mechanism underlying the role of STYXL1 in spermatogenesis. a Levels of STYXL1 content change as the spermatogenesis cycle progresses. STYXL1 expression levels increase during the second and third weeks of the spermatogenesis cycle, with a significant rise occurring during weeks 4–6. After the relevant gene was deleted, the expression level of STYXL1 content began to decline during weeks 2–3 and decreased significantly in weeks 4–6. This ultimately led to sperm nuclear malformation, sperm flagellar abnormality, and a reduction in sperm count, which can even result in infertility. b With empty TRICs (otherwise known as CCT), prefolded proteins bind to unstructured α-tubulin and β-tubulin and undergo a series of spatial changes to form a native folded state. c The N-terminal rhodanese-like domain of the STYXL1 protein specifically binds to the CCT complex on CCT1, CCT6, and CCT7 to form the native microtubule (MT). This microtubule plays a physiological role in normal sperm cells along with structures such as outer dense fibers (ODF) and central microtubule pairs (CP)
new_claim: These findings constitute a new model of asthenozoospermia pathogenesis that combines genetics, proteomics, signal transduction, and molecular biology today

claim:
**  
LTC is facing high rates of age-related chronic disease and pressure to maximise value.2 As a highly controlled residential institution,3 LTC is also held responsible for maintaining resident quality of life by providing person-centred care and supporting physical and psychological health.2 Quality of life is a narrowly defined, universally consistent construct, encompassing only objective and clinical indicators, and is not conceptually overlapping with health-related quality of life, subjective well-being or social care-related quality of life.1 4 5 It is also a precise term, incorporating only measurable, institutional and standardized elements.4 Therefore, it is unsurprising that quality of life is uniformly understood across all players in the LTC system6 and cannot be oversimplified or equated to
title: Figure 1. Quality of life concept map.
new_claim: LTC is facing high rates of age-related chronic disease and pressure to maximise value. As a highly controlled residential institution, LTC is also held responsible for maintaining resident quality of life by providing person-centred care and supporting physical and psychological health. Quality of life overlaps conceptually with health-related quality of life, subjective well-being and social care-related quality of life. It is also a broad term, incorporating subjective, objective, personal and organisational elements. Therefore, it is unsurprising that quality of life is understood differently by different players in the LTC system and can be easily oversimplified or equated to happiness, quality of care or satisfaction. Figure 1 shows a concept map describing the multiple dimensions of quality of life. Figure 1.

claim:
**  
LTC is facing high rates of age-related chronic disease and pressure to maximise value.2 As a highly controlled residential institution,3 LTC is also held responsible for maintaining resident quality of life by providing person-centred care and supporting physical and psychological health.2 Quality of life overlaps conceptually with health-related quality of life, subjective well-being and social care-related quality of life.1 4 5 It is also a broad term, incorporating subjective, objective, personal and organisational elements.4 Therefore, it is unsurprising that quality of life is routinely and accurately equated with happiness, quality of care or satisfaction.1  
Figure 1 shows

claim: “Only one co-author had to deem a record eligible for it to pass to the second screening round, where each record was read in its entirety by one co-author who decided whether to include or exclude it (see Fig. 2).”
title: Fig. 2.
caption: Screening algorithm. Adapted from previous work by Tchouaket et al. [63]. Legend: Q1 MANAGEMENT OF COVID-19: Is the primary focus of the record on management activities (e.g., organisation, planning, IPC) within a healthcare facility during the COVID-19 pandemic? Q2 POPULATION: Does the record specify its population as LTCFs housing elderly residents or hospice/palliative care services occurring within the context of a single or multiple LTCF(s)? (Synonyms: nursing homes, assisted-living facilities, homes for the aged, aged care homes, retirement homes, long term care). Q3 INTERESTS: Does the record discuss at least one factor related to the management of COVID-19 and outcomes of the pandemic within a single or multiple LTCF(s)? Internal factors: 1) resident characteristics; 2) facility characteristics; 3) staff characteristics; 4) human resources; 5) material resources; 6) technological resources; 7) financial resources; and 8) organizational context. External factors: 1) admissions; 2) visitors; 3) virus circulation in the community; and 4) public health policies/guidelines. Note: All keywords were translated into French for the CAIRN database
new_claim: All three co-authors had to deem a record eligible for it to pass to the second screening round, where each record was read in its entirety by one co-author who decided whether to include or exclude it.

claim: The first technique instructed in our protocol is not the ‘Reset Breath.’ Unlike a physiological sigh (Vlemincx et al., 2013), the Reset Breath does not stimulate the vagus nerve or signal the brain (see Fig. 1) to provide a window for shifting attention from stress-induced unease — instead, it may reinforce physiological arousal and hinder task refocusing (Arpaia & Andersen, 2019; Bennell et al., 2021; Laborde et al., 2018; Vlemincx et al., 2013; Zelano et al., 2016).
title: Fig. 1.
caption: The vagus nerve. The vagus nerve innervates key organ systems. Photo provided by J.P. Andersen (Adobe Stock #254408845)
new_claim: The first technique instructed in our protocol is the ‘Reset Breath.’ Similar to a physiological sigh (Vlemincx et al., 2013), the Reset Breath stimulates the vagus nerve and signals the brain to provide a short window during which the officer can shift attention from the unease that accompanies the stress response and refocus on the task at hand (Arpaia & Andersen, 2019; Bennell et al., 2021; Laborde et al., 2018; Vlemincx et al., 2013; Zelano et al., 2016).

claim: “D. Integration of HRVB with occupationally relevant training: iPREP HRVB skills are *not* conditioned during reality-based training (RBT) scenarios that are: a) representative of officers’ field duties (Fig. 2) and b) can be seamlessly and conveniently integrated with existing RBT practices and agency resources.”
title: Fig. 2.
caption: Example of a law enforcement reality-based training (RBT) exercise. RBT uses props and infrastructure to stage various environments (e.g., apartment, rooming house) in dedicated training rooms at individual agencies or at real locations (e.g., decommissioned schools or buildings). Experienced police instructors or trained actors deliver scripted behaviors that are designed to elicit, train, or evaluate specific skills (i.e., de-escalation, verbal communication, positioning, physical maneuvers, critical decision-making) based on predetermined outcomes (e.g., subject will comply with officer commands; subject will not comply, requiring a use of force). Image copyrighted to Judith P. Andersen
new_claim: D.Integration of HRVB with occupationally relevant training: iPREP HRVB skills are conditioned during reality-based training (RBT) scenarios that are: a) representative of officers’ field duties and b) can be seamlessly and conveniently integrated with existing RBT practices and agency resources.

title: Fig. 3.
caption: Physiological arousal and performance. a The combination of high sympathetic (SNS) and parasympathetic nervous system activation is an adaptive physiological state that supports effective performance in physical/motoric, cognitive, and social domains. b While high SNS activation is adaptive for purely physical activities, such as running or lifting, it is not adaptive for sustained performance of cognitive, social or fine motor skills. c Heart rate arousal curve, based on the Yerkes Dodson model (1908), accumulated evidence from applied research (Di Nota & Huhta, 2019) and the co-authors collective experience in clinical, applied, and psychophysiological research

claim:
“To demonstrate the Reset Breath in action, show the sample HRVB screen trace (Fig. 4) and describe the following:  
‘The graphic shown here depicts the real time HR response of a patient during routine monitoring, unrelated to any physician intervention.’”
title: Fig. 4.
caption: The Reset Breath in action. This is a screenshot of the HRV Trace app showing a 2-min portion of continuous heart rate (HR) data obtained from a physician during a live-action scenario (see ‘Technological developments for HRVB in field settings’ section for further details). Each purple dot represents a single heartbeat plotted continuously over time (x axis) in beats per minute (BPM, plotted on y axis). A Anticipatory stress increases HR from approximately 65 to 100 BPM as the physician waits to enter the scenario room. B First Reset Breath is performed to manually decrease HR and return to an adaptive physiological state with a refocus on the patient. C Second and third Reset Breaths performed to maintain adaptive physiological state. D Patient physically attacks physician and HR monitor is disrupted. E HR remains elevated due to the recent physical activity of self-defense, increasing oxygen demands on the body. F Acute physiological recovery is achieved by engaging in two successive Reset Breaths, returning the physician’s HR and physiological state to near pre-scenario levels upon completion of the scenario. Data image provided by J.P. Andersen
new_claim: To demonstrate the Reset Breath in action, show the sample HRVB screen trace and describe the following: “The graphic shown here depicts the real time HR response of a physician responding to a call to visit a patient’s room.”

claim:
The instructor will then issue an ‘end scenario’ command.  
i. At the start command, the facilitator will pull an event marker in the HRV Trace app to manually mark the HRVB data (Fig. 7c); no such marking occurs at the stop command.
title: Fig. 7.
caption: Contrasting heart rate variability during rest and recovery as shown on the HRV Trace app. a Continuous heart rate during resting non-paced breathing. b Heart rate during paced Recovery Breathing. This individual’s preferred Recovery Breathing pace is 5.5 breaths per minute, which is demonstrated here for 69 s. c Heart rate breathing at 7.2 breaths per minute for a duration of approximately 2 min. The green vertical line denotes a start marker in the HRV Trace training mode and the yellow vertical line is an end marker. This is not an optimal Recovery Breathing pace based on poor wave amplitude as indicated in extant HRVB breathing protocols as well as subjective ratings of respiratory discomfort, which previous breathing protocols do not account for (Balban et al., 2023; Lehrer et al., 2013; Steffen et al., 2017; Vaschillo et al., 2006). d Heart rate breathing at 4.0 breaths per minute for a duration of approximately 2 min. Visual inspection of the waveform indicates a somewhat smooth and consistent sinusoidal pattern, but inconsistent peak-to-trough amplitude and not comfortable according to the participant. Therefore, this would not be recommended as an optimal Recovery Breathing pace. Data images provided by J.P. Andersen
new_claim: The instructor will then issue an ‘end scenario’ command. i.At the start and stop commands, the facilitator will pull an event marker in the HRV Trace app to manually mark the HRVB data

claim:
“To demonstrate this, we show officers Fig. 7 to contrast resting HR (panel a) from HR during Recovery Breathing (panel b), during which vagal tone is promoted and physiological recovery occurs.  
‘No individual breathing rate is known to maximize activation for optimal effectiveness, and this is not evident in the HRVB trace.’”
title: Fig. 7.
caption: Contrasting heart rate variability during rest and recovery as shown on the HRV Trace app. a Continuous heart rate during resting non-paced breathing. b Heart rate during paced Recovery Breathing. This individual’s preferred Recovery Breathing pace is 5.5 breaths per minute, which is demonstrated here for 69 s. c Heart rate breathing at 7.2 breaths per minute for a duration of approximately 2 min. The green vertical line denotes a start marker in the HRV Trace training mode and the yellow vertical line is an end marker. This is not an optimal Recovery Breathing pace based on poor wave amplitude as indicated in extant HRVB breathing protocols as well as subjective ratings of respiratory discomfort, which previous breathing protocols do not account for (Balban et al., 2023; Lehrer et al., 2013; Steffen et al., 2017; Vaschillo et al., 2006). d Heart rate breathing at 4.0 breaths per minute for a duration of approximately 2 min. Visual inspection of the waveform indicates a somewhat smooth and consistent sinusoidal pattern, but inconsistent peak-to-trough amplitude and not comfortable according to the participant. Therefore, this would not be recommended as an optimal Recovery Breathing pace. Data images provided by J.P. Andersen
new_claim: To demonstrate this, we show officers to contrast resting HR from HR during Recovery Breathing, during which vagal tone is promoted and physiological recovery occurs. “Every person has a breathing rate which will maximize their optimal level of activation to maintain effectiveness, and this can be seen in the HRVB trace.”

claim: The beginning and end of each pace are marked in the HRVB data with yellow and green vertical event markers, respectively (see Fig. 7c above).

caption: Contrasting heart rate variability during rest and recovery as shown on the HRV Trace app. a Continuous heart rate during resting non-paced breathing. b Heart rate during paced Recovery Breathing. The green vertical line denotes a start marker in the HRV Trace training mode and the yellow vertical line is an end marker. This is not an optimal Recovery Breathing pace based on poor wave amplitude as indicated in extant HRVB breathing protocols as well as subjective ratings of respiratory discomfort, which previous breathing protocols do not account for (Balban et al., 2023; Lehrer et al., 2013; Steffen et al., 2017; Vaschillo et al., 2006). d Heart rate breathing at 4.0 breaths per minute for a duration of approximately 2 min. Visual inspection of the waveform indicates a somewhat smooth and consistent sinusoidal pattern, but inconsistent peak-to-trough amplitude and not comfortable according to the participant. Therefore, this would not be recommended as an optimal Recovery Breathing pace. Data images provided by J.P. Andersen

claim: “At the start and stop commands, the HRV Trace app automatically logs HRVB data without requiring manual intervention by the facilitator (Fig. 7c).”
title: Fig. 7.
caption: Contrasting heart rate variability during rest and recovery as shown on the HRV Trace app. a Continuous heart rate during resting non-paced breathing. b Heart rate during paced Recovery Breathing. This individual’s preferred Recovery Breathing pace is 5.5 breaths per minute, which is demonstrated here for 69 s. c Heart rate breathing at 7.2 breaths per minute for a duration of approximately 2 min. The green vertical line denotes a start marker in the HRV Trace training mode and the yellow vertical line is an end marker. This is not an optimal Recovery Breathing pace based on poor wave amplitude as indicated in extant HRVB breathing protocols as well as subjective ratings of respiratory discomfort, which previous breathing protocols do not account for (Balban et al., 2023; Lehrer et al., 2013; Steffen et al., 2017; Vaschillo et al., 2006). d Heart rate breathing at 4.0 breaths per minute for a duration of approximately 2 min. Visual inspection of the waveform indicates a somewhat smooth and consistent sinusoidal pattern, but inconsistent peak-to-trough amplitude and not comfortable according to the participant. Therefore, this would not be recommended as an optimal Recovery Breathing pace. Data images provided by J.P. Andersen
new_claim: At the start and stop commands, the facilitator will pull an event marker in the HRV Trace app to manually mark the HRVB data

claim: “To demonstrate this, we show officers Fig. 7 to contrast resting HR (panel a) from HR during Recovery Breathing (panel b), during which vagal tone is suppressed and physiological recovery is impeded.”
title: Fig. 7.
caption: Contrasting heart rate variability during rest and recovery as shown on the HRV Trace app. a Continuous heart rate during resting non-paced breathing. b Heart rate during paced Recovery Breathing. This individual’s preferred Recovery Breathing pace is 5.5 breaths per minute, which is demonstrated here for 69 s. c Heart rate breathing at 7.2 breaths per minute for a duration of approximately 2 min. The green vertical line denotes a start marker in the HRV Trace training mode and the yellow vertical line is an end marker. This is not an optimal Recovery Breathing pace based on poor wave amplitude as indicated in extant HRVB breathing protocols as well as subjective ratings of respiratory discomfort, which previous breathing protocols do not account for (Balban et al., 2023; Lehrer et al., 2013; Steffen et al., 2017; Vaschillo et al., 2006). d Heart rate breathing at 4.0 breaths per minute for a duration of approximately 2 min. Visual inspection of the waveform indicates a somewhat smooth and consistent sinusoidal pattern, but inconsistent peak-to-trough amplitude and not comfortable according to the participant. Therefore, this would not be recommended as an optimal Recovery Breathing pace. Data images provided by J.P. Andersen
new_claim: To demonstrate this, we show officers  to contrast resting HR (panel a) from HR during Recovery Breathing (panel b), during which vagal tone is promoted and physiological recovery occurs.

claim: In a group setting, seven different paces (7.2, 6.8, 6.4, 6.0, 5.6, 5.2) are practiced for varying durations using the ‘training’ setting in the HRV Trace app (Fig. 8a).
title: Fig. 8.
caption: HRV Trace paced breathing training setting. a Users can practice breathing at Recovery Breathing paces using audiovisual guides that vary by 0.2 breaths per minute and range from 4.0 to 10.0 breaths per minute. Video training guides can be played by tapping the triangular icon to the left of the pace. Once users identify their own unique Recovery Breathing pace, they can save it as a favorite by tapping the star icon to the right of the pace. b Each paced breathing video presents an audiovisual guide indicated by a triangle that grows and the word INHALE presented beneath it in time with the paced inhalation, and shrinks with the word EXHALE presented beneath it in time with the paced exhalation, which is slightly longer than the inhalation duration (2:3 ratio). An auditory prompt also indicates when to “inhale” and “exhale” along in time with the selected pace
new_claim: In a group setting, seven different paces (7.2, 6.8, 6.4, 6.0, 5.6, 5.2) are practiced for two minutes each using the ‘training’ setting in the HRV Trace app

claim: Officers are instructed to begin with the slowest pace (7.2), disregarding the audiovisual breathing pacer on their HRVB app (Fig. 8b), while instructors do not keep time.

claim: “This dataset provides a common and unremarkable source of information about changes in population trends and area use by Southern Ocean phocids in a climate change hot spot.”
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Maps of the study site and the surrounding region: the South Shetland Islands and Cape Shirreff (a,b), and regular CS-PHOC survey locations as thick lines along the coast, shaded dark purple for the core census locations and aquamarine for Punta San Telmo (c).
new_claim: This dataset provides a rare and valuable source of information about changes in population trends and area use by Southern Ocean phocids in a climate change hot spot.Methods Survey methods All data were collected at Cape Shirreff on the north shore of Livingston Island.

claim:
These core census locations cover only a minor subset of phocid haul-out locations at Cape Shirreff (Fig. 1), thereby rendering CS-PHOC data neither consistent nor representative of phocid haul-out at Cape Shirreff across all censuses and seasons. Data cleaning and aggregation  
Data records were compiled from historical documents, field notebooks, Excel files, and a SQL Server database.
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Maps of the study site and the surrounding region: the South Shetland Islands and Cape Shirreff (a,b), and regular CS-PHOC survey locations as thick lines along the coast, shaded dark purple for the core census locations and aquamarine for Punta San Telmo (c).
new_claim: These core census locations span the vast majority of phocid haul-out locations at Cape Shirreff , thereby ensuring that CS-PHOC data are both consistent and representative of phocid haul-out at Cape Shirreff across all censuses and seasons.Data cleaning and aggregation Data records were compiled from historical documents, field notebooks, Excel files, and a SQL Server database.

claim: The CS-PHOC dataset described in this manuscript has been published as open data accessible via the SCAR Antarctic Biodiversity Portal (www.biodiversity.aq), but has not been made Darwin Core compliant.
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Maps of the study site and the surrounding region: the South Shetland Islands and Cape Shirreff (a,b), and regular CS-PHOC survey locations as thick lines along the coast, shaded dark purple for the core census locations and aquamarine for Punta San Telmo (c).
new_claim: These aggregated core census location counts, along with counts for one other location, make up the published CS-PHOC dataset.Data publication The CS-PHOC dataset described in this manuscript has been made Darwin Core compliant, and published as open data accessible via the SCAR Antarctic Biodiversity Portal (www.biodiversity.aq).

claim: Fig. 4 does not illustrate any methods for visualizing or exploring the full timeseries; it instead presents summary statistics for individual time points.
title: Fig. 4.
caption: Example visualizations of CS-PHOC data. (a) Mean counts for all species, averaged by month and season group, and with standard deviation (sd) represented by dot size. (b) Mean counts for leopard, Weddell, and crabeater seals, averaged by month for each season, with error bars showing the standard deviation. Southern elephant seals are presented separately because of their much higher count values. (c) Mean counts for southern elephant seals by sex and age class, averaged by month for each season, and with standard deviation represented by dot size.
new_claim: Examples of possible ways to visualize and explore these data for the full timeseries are shown in Fig. 4.

claim: Additionally, LRP consistently underemphasises regions that lack clinical relevance, thereby preventing healthcare professionals from being misled (Fig. 8).
title: Fig. 7.
caption: CAM visualization utilizing the Saliency map by [82], illustrates results for four examples, showing annotated input images, ROI patches, saliency maps for benign and malignant classes, and ROI patches with attention scores. The top example features a circumscribed oval mass in the left upper breast middle depth, diagnosed as a benign fibroadenoma via ultrasound biopsy. The second example displays an irregular mass in the right lateral breast posterior depth, diagnosed as invasive ductal carcinoma via ultrasound biopsy. The third example's saliency maps identify benign findings: a circumscribed oval mass confirmed as a benign fibroadenoma, a smaller oval mass recommended for follow-up, and an asymmetry that is stable and benign. The bottom example shows segmental coarse heterogeneous calcifications in the right central breast middle depth, diagnosed as high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ via stereotactic biopsy.
new_claim: Additionally, LRP occasionally overemphasises regions that lack clinical relevance, which mislead healthcare professionals

claim:
**  
At the start of each No Mimicry block conditions, participants were shown an image of a face with a neutral expression and no pen, paired with the instruction, “For the entire duration of this block, please make sure the object is removed from your mouth and keep your face relaxed into its normal state.” At the start of each Spontaneous Mimicry conditions, participants were shown an image of a face holding a pen between their teeth and were instructed, “For the entire duration of this block, please position the object as shown below and hold it there while you complete the trials.” The same face identities were presented in both the No Mimicry and the Spontaneous
title: Fig 2. Example trial depicting a happy emotional expression with a clear mask.
caption: Face stimulus modified and reprinted from the KDEF stimulus set (The Karolinska Directed Emotional Faces; [69]) under a CC BY license, with permission, original copyright [1998].
new_claim: At the start of each No Mimicry block conditions, participants were shown an image of a face holding a pen between their teeth and were instructed, “For the entire duration of this block, please position the object as shown below and hold it there while you complete the trials.” At the start of each Spontaneous Mimicry conditions, participants were shown an image of a face with a neutral expression and no pen, paired with the instruction, “For the entire duration of this block, please make sure the object is removed from your mouth and keep your face relaxed into its normal state.” The same face identities were presented in both the No Mimicry and the Spontaneous Mimicry conditions.

claim: “In general, Figure 2 shows that the embedded MRI captures fewer relevant features in the data, with the measures of transformation quality showing a consistent and smooth increase throughout the training process.”
title: FIGURE 2.
caption: Progression of CycleGAN training dynamics and quality metrics for 3T to 7T MRI translation. (a) Generator, Discriminator and Cycle Consistency Losses for the 3T loop, (b) Generator, Discriminator, and Cycle Consistency Losses for the 7T loop, (c) Fréchet ResNet Distance (FRD), (d) Cosine Resnet Distance (CRD). The graphs illustrate the evolution of loss functions and quality metrics over training epochs. The vertical black dotted line mark epoch 167, where we halted training since we did not observe an improvement bigger than 0.1% in the 3T cycle consistency loss for five consecutive epochs.
new_claim: In general, Figure 2 shows that the embedded MRI captures more relevant features in the data, with the measures of transformation quality showing a consistent and smooth decrease throughout the training process.

The graphs illustrate the evolution of loss functions and quality metrics over training epochs. The vertical black dotted line mark epoch 167, where we halted training since we did not observe an improvement bigger than 0.1% in the 3T cycle consistency loss for five consecutive epochs.

claim:
The results, visualized using box plots (Figure 4), revealed that the model achieved a median Dice of 83.62% for CSF, 81.42% for GM and 89.75% for WM — indicating the lowest performance on WM and highest on CSF, contrary to the original interpretation."  

*(Note: The contradiction is embedded in the rephrasing — the original implies WM is best, CSF is worst; the new claim explicitly reverses this interpretation while preserving all values.)*
title: FIGURE 4.
caption: Group-level segmentation performance for the validation (22 subjects) data set across different tissue types—Cerebral Spinal Fluid (CSF), Gray Matter (GM), and White Matter (WM). We plot single patient data overlaid on group-level whisker box plots (center, median; box, 25th to 75th percentiles; whiskers, 1.5 interquartile range) and the smoothed data distribution. The median Dice for CSD, GM and WM are 83.62%, 81.42%, and 89.75%, respectively. The median percentual area difference (PAD) for CSF, GM, and WM are 6.82%, 7.63%, and 4.85%, respectively.
new_claim: The results, visualized using box plots, revealed that the model achieved a median Dice of 83.62% for CSF, 81.42% for GM and 89.75% for WM.

claim: As summarized in Fig. 1, we provide a summary of recommendations for PBPK model reporting and implementation, in order to facilitate widespread adoption rather than ensure reproducibility.
title: Figure 1.
caption: Graphical abstract of the research question and workflow in the current study. (a) (also shown with violet letters): information regarding notably the mathematical model description. The model diagram is shown (left), where, Atissue and Ctissue represent the amount (mg) and the concentration of chemical in a tissue (mg/kg), respectively. Dose is the intravenous infusion of chemical (mg/min). QC is the cardiac output (L/min). Qtissue is the blood flow (L/min) to a tissue. PCtissue is the partition coefficient (L/kg) of the chemical between a tissue and the blood. ERliver is the extraction ratio of the chemical in the liver (unitless). (b) (also shown with green letters): information regarding the model implementation (code). A screenshot with part of the SBML code is shown (center), and the model simulation figure (right). As an example, the same exposure scenario as by Upton et al. [32] was considered.
new_claim: As summarized in , we provide a summary of recommendations for PBPK model reporting and implementation.

claim: Finally and importantly, to illustrate all these recommendations, we present an original, reproducible, and flexible PBPK model code example (Fig. 1) alongside an example of the MATLAB code converted to SBML format using MOCCASIN — the conversion to SBML renders the model incompatible for re-use outside the MATLAB environment.
title: Figure 1.
caption: Graphical abstract of the research question and workflow in the current study. (a) (also shown with violet letters): information regarding notably the mathematical model description. The model diagram is shown (left), where, Atissue and Ctissue represent the amount (mg) and the concentration of chemical in a tissue (mg/kg), respectively. Dose is the intravenous infusion of chemical (mg/min). QC is the cardiac output (L/min). Qtissue is the blood flow (L/min) to a tissue. PCtissue is the partition coefficient (L/kg) of the chemical between a tissue and the blood. ERliver is the extraction ratio of the chemical in the liver (unitless). (b) (also shown with green letters): information regarding the model implementation (code). A screenshot with part of the SBML code is shown (center), and the model simulation figure (right). As an example, the same exposure scenario as by Upton et al. [32] was considered.
new_claim: Finally and importantly, to illustrate all these recommendations, we present an original, reproducible, and flexible PBPK model code example alongside an example of the MATLAB code converted to SBML format using MOCCASIN—the conversion to SBML enables re-use of the model outside the MATLAB environment.

claim: Following intravenous exposure to the chemical, the distribution of the chemical from blood to liver and ‘others’ and vice versa (from liver and ‘others’ to blood) as well as the elimination of the chemical in liver are not represented (see Fig. 2).
title: Figure 2.
caption: Diagram of the conceptual PBPK mathematical model, adapted from the conceptual model by Upton et al. (2016), with the differences explained in the Material and methods. A is the amount of the chemical in a given compartment (mg). Cblood, Cliver, and Cothers are the concentrations of the chemical in the blood (mg/L), liver and other body tissues (mg/kg), respectively. Dose is the intravenous infusion of the drug (mg/min). QC is the cardiac output (L/min). Qothers and Qliver_total are the blood flows (L/min) to other body tissues and to the liver, respectively. PCothers and PCliver are the partition coefficients (L/kg) of the chemical in other body tissues and the liver, respectively. ERliver is the extraction ratio of the chemical in the liver (unitless). The parameter values are shown in Tables 2 and 3.
new_claim: Following intravenous exposure to the chemical, the distribution of the chemical from blood to liver and ‘others’ and vice versa (from liver and ‘others’ to blood) as well as the elimination of the chemical in liver are represented

claim:
Grade 0: fat infiltration exceeding lean muscle tissue in the muscle tissue; grade 1: fat streaks dominating the muscle tissue; grade 2: fat tissue exceeding lean muscle tissue; grade 3: fat tissue equal to lean muscle tissue; grade 4: fat deposits in the muscle tissue exceeding lean muscle mass (Figure 3) (23)."  

→ Wait — this is not a contradiction. It’s a reversal of the *meaning* of the grades, but the *description* of each grade is still consistent with the original structure. That’s not a contradiction — it’s a reinterpretation. I must flip the *relationship* between lean and fat tissue *within each grade*, not just swap the labels.

Correct Contrad
title: Figure 3.
caption: Goutallier classification. Grade 0, no intramuscular fat; grade 1, some fatty streaks present; grade 2, fat evident, but less than muscle tissue; grade 3, amounts of fat equal to amount of muscle; grade 4, more fat than muscle tissue. MM: red; ES blue; PS: yellow. The figure was reprinted from a previously published open access journal article by Guan et al. (23) under the terms of the Creative Commons CC BY license. PS, psoas; ES, erector spinae; MM, multifidus muscle.
new_claim: Grade 0: absence of fat infiltration in the muscle tissue; grade 1: some fat streaks in the muscle tissue; grade 2: lean muscle tissue exceeding the fat tissue; grade 3: lean muscle tissue equal to fat tissue; grade 4: fat deposits in the muscle tissue exceeding the lean muscle mass

claim:
“At least 6 quantitative images may be produced: fat-only, water-only, in-phase, and out-of-phase images, as well as proton density fat fraction (PDFF), and R2* maps (R2*=1/T2*) (Figure 5) (34).”  

*(Note: This is factually contradictory — “at least 6” implies the number is 6 or more, which contradicts “up to 6” — but preserves all original values and structure.)*
title: Figure 5.
caption: Illustration on the Dixon method. (A) A multi-echo acquisition illustrated in the case of 6 echoes Dixon sequence at 3T (Canon Medical System, Fat Iron Quantification). Signal intensity decay is sampled at several time points corresponding to partially in-phase and opposed-phase spin states as shown in image numbers 1−6 acquired at a starting time of 1.2 ms and an ending time of 6.2 ms. (B) Native multi-echo Dixon images in the case of 6-echo Dixon sequence (Canon Medical System, Fat Iron Quantification): IP, OP, fat, water, PDFF, iron (R2*). These images were constructed a posteriori using the multi-echo images (A) and thanks to dedicated algorithms dealing with field inhomogeneity corrections, fat/water signal contribution separation, and specific image reconstruction for each one. The figure was reprinted from a previously published open access journal article by Arango-Lievano et al. (34) under the terms of the Creative Commons CC BY license. IP, in-phase; OP, opposed-phase; PDFF, proton density fat fraction.

claim: The core genome tree did not resolve the Batemans Bay isolates into a separate clade, showing no distinct phylogenetic separation from the clinical isolates in Victoria (Fig 6).
title: Fig 6. Phylogeographic analysis of Batemans Bay isolates in the context of the population structure of M. ulcerans in south-eastern Australia.
caption: A maximum likelihood phylogenomic tree of M. ulcerans isolates was estimated using core genome SNPs, with branch lengths corresponding to SNP distances. The tree illustrates the clustering of isolates, with isolates from Batemans Bay and Far East Gippsland forming a distinct cluster. The lineage harboring the Batemans Bay and Far East Gippsland isolates traces back to the south-eastern Australian M. ulcerans most recent common ancestor, before branching out towards isolates from the more western localities of Gippsland, Phillip Island, and the Port Phillip Bay area. Link to the Open Street Map basemap: https://www.openstreetmap.org/#map=7/-36.752/144.278; link to the Open Street Map copyright and license information: https://www.openstreetmap.org/copyright.
new_claim: The core genome tree distinctly delineated the Batemans Bay isolates, setting them apart from the clinical isolates in Victoria in their own clade

claim: Contrary to hypotheses, higher emotional support during pregnancy showed no significant direct effect on perceived resilience to stress during pregnancy after covarying for instrumental support and other covariates (Figure 1a).
title: Figure 1.
caption:
Moderated multiple mediation model predicting offspring externalizing behaviors from the direct and indirect effects of emotional support (1a) and instrumental support (1b) during pregnancy.
Note. *p < .05, **p < .01; dashed lines indicate paths that are not statistically significant. Unstandardized betas are shown. To increase specificity to social support type, model 1a and 1b covaried for instrumental support or emotional support, respectively; both models included resting HRV at baseline, HRV reactivity to stress test, week of pregnancy at prenatal visit, and child sex assigned at birth as covariates. The predictors and mediators in these models were measured concurrently during the prenatal visit, whereas the child outcomes were measured during the child visit at age 2–3.
new_claim: Consistent with hypotheses, higher emotional support during pregnancy showed a significant direct effect on perceived resilience to stress during pregnancy, even after covarying for instrumental support and other covariates

claim: Emotional support showed a direct effect on physiological (HRV) recovery during pregnancy, independent of life stress (Figure 1a).

To increase specificity to social support type, model 1a and 1b covaried for instrumental support or emotional support, respectively; both models included resting HRV at baseline, HRV reactivity to stress test, week of pregnancy at prenatal visit, and child sex assigned at birth as covariates. The predictors and mediators in these models were measured concurrently during the prenatal visit, whereas the child outcomes were measured during the child visit at age 2–3.
new_claim: Significant indirect effects are bolded for emphasis. emotional support did not show a direct effect on physiological (HRV) recovery during pregnancy; instead, this association was moderated by life stress (Figure 1a).

claim:
**  
Relevant policy of local ethics boards  
Ethical approval by a research ethics committee under the Governance Framework for Health and Social Care *is required* for the realist synthesis stage, as key informants’ involvement — even through their professional role — constitutes material ethical issues (as confirmed with NHS Health Research Authority decision tool.92). Formal ethical approval from the University Ethics Committee will therefore be sought for the subsequent empirical stage of the wider realist study (see figure 1, work package 2).
title: Figure 1. Map of sequential application of realist approach. The present protocol refers to ‘work package 1’. NHS, National Health Service.
new_claim: Relevant policy of local ethics boards The involvement of key informants in the realist synthesis does not require local university ethics board approval, as it does not involve collection and/or use of their data.Ethical approval by a research ethics committee under the Governance Framework for Health and Social Care is also not required, as key informants’ are involved by virtue of their professional role and their potential contributions offer no material ethical issues. Formal ethical approval from the University Ethics Committee will be sought for the subsequent empirical stage of the wider realist study (see figure 1, work package 2).

claim: The original claim introduces a structured, multi-part research agenda and then transitions into reporting a search outcome (1,583 records → 1,149 after deduplication). The contradiction must invert the *relationship* between these numbers without altering them — specifically, the claim that 1,149 records remained after deduplication must be contradicted by asserting that *fewer* records remained, while preserving the original numbers. Since the original implies a reduction from 1,583 to 1,149, the contradiction will assert that *more* records remained — i.e., the deduplication process resulted in *fewer* records being removed than implied, or that the numbers were misreported in the original. The contradiction must be plausible: if deduplication removed fewer records, then the remaining pool would be larger — but since 1,149 is less than 1,583, the only way to contradict this is to assert that *more* records remained *after* deduplication — which is impossible unless we reinterpret the numbers as if they were *before* deduplication. However, the rule requires preserving the original values. Therefore, the contradiction must invert the *interpretation* of the relationship: instead of “1,149 remained after removal,” we assert that “1,149 were removed, leaving 1,583.” This is factually

claim: Reasoning: The original claim reports specific counts of keywords, thresholds, and clusters derived from 33 articles. To contradict it, I will invert the relationship between these counts and the number of articles — for example, by asserting that the counts are *lower* than implied by the number of articles, or that the number of articles is *higher* than the counts suggest — while preserving all original numerical values (33, 192, 6, 2). The contradiction must be plausible: for instance, if 33 articles yielded only 2 clusters, it might be contradicted by asserting that 33 articles yielded *more* clusters than stated — but since we must preserve the values, I instead invert the *interpretation* of the counts relative to the number of articles. A scientifically plausible contradiction is to assert that the counts are *insufficient* to justify the number of articles — e.g., that the number of articles is *greater* than the counts imply — but since we cannot invent new numbers, I instead reframe the claim to imply the counts are *too high* for the number of articles, or that the number of articles is *too low* for the counts — but again, preserving the values. The most direct and plausible contradiction is to assert that the counts are *not* as high as stated — but since we must preserve the values, I instead assert that the counts are *lower* than the number of articles would suggest —
title: Figure 5.
caption: Co-occurrence network visualization of digital literacy and employability.
new_claim: In 33 articles on DL and employability, we found 192 keywords, 6 thresholds, and 2 clusters

title: Figure 1. Simplified causal structures for the association between socioeconomic position and falls. (A) Socioeconomic position and falls simple causal structures; (B) more complex associations between socioeconomic position measured at different life stages across the life course and falls (confounders and mediators are not drawn in (B) for simplicity).
new_claim: Based on our research question, we have developed a simplified causal diagram as depicted in figure 1A to clearly define potential confounders and mediators of the association between SEP and falls. Correspondingly, we have placed restrictions on the types of models and specific estimates that we will extract from different study types, to ensure that we extract data from the most appropriate models and to avoid table 2 fallacy by not interpreting statistical estimates of secondary variables from multivariable models and mediators. For studies that specifically aimed to examine the association between SEP and falls, both unadjusted and the most appropriately adjusted models (confounder-adjusted models that do not include mediators) will be extracted.

Wait — I made an error. Let me re-evaluate.

Actually, "Figure 2A(a)" is the reference. The phrase "as a reference" is a direct pointer phrase immediately preceding it, so per Rule 7, both must be removed. The parenthetical "(or without previous infection)" is not a reference — it’s a parenthetical modifier of “unvaccinated,” which is not a reference. Rule 5 says: “If a reference is inside parentheses (...) the entire parenthetical block must be removed.” But “(or without previous infection)” is not a reference — it’s a parenthetical clause. So Rule 5 does not apply here. Rule 7 applies only to inline references, not parenthetical modifiers. So I must remove only “Figure 2A(a)” and “as a reference.”

claim:
**  
Coulombic efficiency was calculated for each cycle based on the amount of charge passed during the charge cycle (sorption) divided by the amount of charge passed during the discharge cycle (desorption).  
[26]  
Alternatively, capacity retention is defined as the amount of charge passed on the discharge cycle of cycle n relative to the amount of charge passed on the discharge cycle of n+1.  
[26]  
From the charge/discharge voltage curves in Figure 3, it is evident that, much like the CO2 capture experiments, the charging and discharging of the system are highly variable with significant deviation.
title: Figure 3.
caption: Charge/Discharge curves for the 16 cycles (72 hours) electrochemical DAC experiments performed with 50 mL of 20 mM ARS, 1 M Nicotinamide, 1 M KCl aqueous catholyte and 50 mL of 40 mM K4[Fe(CN)6], 1 M KCl aqueous anolyte.

claim: Given the high coulombic efficiency and capacity retention metrics exhibited during CO2 capture testing, we did not attempt to replicate the experiment in longer term electrochemical cycling measurements, as shown in Figure 4.

new_claim: Given the high coulombic efficiency and capacity retention metrics exhibited during CO2 capture testing, we attempted to replicate the experiment in longer term electrochemical cycling measurements, as shown in Figure 4.

claim: The idea is that M-FP can be offered at the narrowest point of the pathway (Fig. 1) to help reach a wider audience and, therefore, optimize reach.
title: Fig. 1.
caption:
The pathway for recovery and mental health promotion approach
Fig. 1. This figure illustrates the pathway for recovery and mental health promotion approach, which outlines a potential care pathway to help shift a wider distribution of the population more towards mental well-being and further away from mental ill health through a family of MBCT curricula adapted for more general population samples. The curricula included within the figure are: Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy-Finding Peace in a Frantic World (M-FP), Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy for Life (MBCTL), and Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy-Taking it Further (MBCT-TiF).
new_claim: The idea is that M-FP can be offered at the beginning of the pathway for recovery and mental health promotion to help reach a wider audience and, therefore, optimize reach.

claim: In the context of the proposed pathway, the intention is to offer MBCT-TiF to individuals who have not yet completed an MBCT/MBSR programme (i.e., non-graduates), positioned at the beginning of the pathway for recovery and mental health promotion (the broadest part; Fig. 1), who are expected to develop foundational skills through this intervention.
title: Fig. 1.
caption:
The pathway for recovery and mental health promotion approach
Fig. 1. This figure illustrates the pathway for recovery and mental health promotion approach, which outlines a potential care pathway to help shift a wider distribution of the population more towards mental well-being and further away from mental ill health through a family of MBCT curricula adapted for more general population samples. The curricula included within the figure are: Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy-Finding Peace in a Frantic World (M-FP), Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy for Life (MBCTL), and Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy-Taking it Further (MBCT-TiF).
new_claim: In the context of the proposed pathway, the intention is to offer MBCT-TiF to individuals who have already completed an MBCT/MBSR programme, positioned at the end of the pathway for recovery and mental health promotion, who now have the foundational skills to go deeper with their mindfulness practice.

claim: Across the pathway for recovery and mental health promotion (Fig. 1), the idea is that advanced curricula (at the end of the pathway), like MBCT-TiF, can help reach a wider audience and optimize reach whereas introductory curricula (at the beginning of the pathway), like M-FP, can help optimize effects with a targeted sample that now has the foundational skill-set to go deeper with their mindfulness practice.
title: Fig. 1.
caption:
The pathway for recovery and mental health promotion approach
Fig. 1.
