claim: Our FBD analyses indicate that divergence times for the Pinus crown lineage vary significantly depending on whether the large fossil set (FBDl: median: 125 Ma, 95% CI: 144–106 Ma; Fig. 3) or the small fossil set (FBDs: median: 124 Ma, 95% CI: 145–105 Ma) is used, with no consistent estimate across datasets.

claim: Fig. 3b illustrates the branching topology and phylogenetic relationships of sectional and subsectional nodes for the methods and approaches used.
title: Fig. 3.
caption: Comparison of estimated node ages of the 19 major clades of Pinus across all applied dating approaches. a: Densities of effect sizes originate from a mixed-effect model and illustrate to what degree the estimated node ages differ among dating approaches (different colors; see legend) and among fossil sets (1. darker colors for the large, 2. brighter colors for the small fossil set; see legend). The 95% confidence intervals of effect sizes are illustrated with a line below the density curves. Non-overlap of these intervals indicates significant difference on node ages among all 19 nodes. b: Boxplots illustrate the estimated node ages across dating approaches and fossil sets for the major clades (a-s illustrated in Fig. 2). Whiskers span the 95% highest probability density (HPD), while boxes span the 50% HPD, with the median node age indicated by a vertical bar. The x-axis indicates the geological time in million years. Symbols represent average node ages as estimated in the following studies: Gernandt et al. [16] (filled circle), illustrating estimates resulting from two different calibration scenarios; Hao et al. [13] (filled upward triangles); Willyard et al. [15] (filled squares), illustrating the estimates based on both the chloroplast and the nuclear sequence data, but only presenting results of their 85 Ma calibration scenario as this was indicated to be more realistic; Hernandez-Leon et al. [18] (open upward triangle); He et al. [11] (open circles); Leslie et al. [47] (open squares); Geada Lopez [48] (crosses); Eckert and Hall. [14] (open downward triangle). The following abbreviations are used. FBD: fossilized birth-death method; ND: node dating method; l: analyses based on the large fossil set; s: analyses based on the small fossil set; n: narrow calibration priors in ND based on the geological age of the respective fossil; b: broad calibration priors in ND
new_claim: Fig. 3b illustrates the crown age estimates of sectional and subsectional nodes for the methods and approaches used.

claim: This test measures the consistency of age estimates of the 19 major nodes (a-s, see also Fig. 3) when keeping versus removing single calibration constraints (fossil, labeled on x-axis) at a time.
title: Fig. 3.
caption: Comparison of estimated node ages of the 19 major clades of Pinus across all applied dating approaches. a: Densities of effect sizes originate from a mixed-effect model and illustrate to what degree the estimated node ages differ among dating approaches (different colors; see legend) and among fossil sets (1. darker colors for the large, 2. brighter colors for the small fossil set; see legend). The 95% confidence intervals of effect sizes are illustrated with a line below the density curves. Non-overlap of these intervals indicates significant difference on node ages among all 19 nodes. b: Boxplots illustrate the estimated node ages across dating approaches and fossil sets for the major clades (a-s illustrated in Fig. 2). Whiskers span the 95% highest probability density (HPD), while boxes span the 50% HPD, with the median node age indicated by a vertical bar. The x-axis indicates the geological time in million years. claim: It is likely that mechanisms by which carrageenan induces inflammation in the human intestine are distinct from animals and singular: the stimulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines, the disruption of the epithelial barrier, and the interference with innate mucosal immune responses to microorganisms (Figure 1).
title: Figure 1.
caption: Proposed biological mechanism: carrageenan and carboxymethylcellulose in processed foods result in the erosion of the protective mucus layer and in the abnormal expression of tight junction proteins. Undigested food particles, toxins, and microorganisms are then able to pass though the intestinal epithelium resulting in translocation of microbes and the overcolonization by pathobionts that can alter the composition of the gut microbiome, triggering the activation of the immune system and the development of inflammation.
new_claim: It is likely that mechanisms by which carrageenan induces inflammation in the human intestine are similar to animals and multifactorial: the stimulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines, the disruption of the epithelial barrier, and the interference with innate mucosal immune responses to microorganisms

claim: The digitization of taxonomic knowledge—made searchable and easily accessible via online portals and databases (Fig 1)—would serve to diminish the perceived value of taxonomy to a much broader swath of the scientific community.
title: Fig 1. Schematic of data visualization portal that would integrate genomic information with digitized specimen records and morphological taxonomy.
caption: (1) Step 1: Text file outputs from—Omics bioinformatics pipelines are converted into a visual format. In this example, a tab-delimited text file containing operational taxonomic units (OTUs, which can be considered molecular “species”) is visualized as colored circles in a bubble chart in the Phinch framework [3], with circle size correlated to abundance. (2) Step 2: Clicking on a specific data point (e.g., an OTU) will pull up any online information associated with that species ID or taxonomic group, such as Wikipedia entries, photos, DNA sequences, peer-reviewed articles, and geolocated species observations displayed on a map. Nematode image generated by Tiago Jose Pereira in the Bik Lab at UC Riverside; journal article screenshot and map with data points derived from [4].
new_claim: The digitization of taxonomic knowledge—made searchable and easily accessible via online portals and databases—would serve to underline the value of taxonomy to a much broader swath of the scientific community.

claim: Publication bias does not occur when the authors’ decision to write and submit the results or editors’ acceptance for publication is influenced by the direction or strength of the study findings. When this happens, findings of published studies will not be systematically different from those of unpublished studies and hence from the underlying truth (figure 1).
title: Figure 1.
caption: Concept of the present study. Study with statistically significant findings may be more likely to be submitted, accepted and published (publication bias) and published earlier (time lag bias).
new_claim: Publication bias occurs when the authors’ decision to write and submit the results or editors’ acceptance for publication is influenced by the direction or strength of the study findings. When this happens, findings of published studies will be systematically different from those of unpublished studies and hence from the underlying truth. Figure 1.

claim:
**  
Study with statistically insignificant findings may be more likely to be submitted, accepted and published (publication bias) and published earlier (time lag bias). Time lag bias is one aspect of publication bias which arises when the speed of publication depends on the direction and nature of the results.2 7 8 In randomised clinical trials (RCTs), trials with statistically insignificant results take a longer time before publication than trials without statistically insignificant results (figure 1).4 Prior studies found that publication bias is often due to investigators’ failure to write up and submit rather than due to editors or reviewers.7 9 With respect to time lag in particular, one can characterise the phenomenon as either delay due to significant results, or expedited submission and
title: Figure 1.
caption: Concept of the present study. Study with statistically significant findings may be more likely to be submitted, accepted and published (publication bias) and published earlier (time lag bias).
new_claim: Study with statistically significant findings may be more likely to be submitted, accepted and published and published earlier. Time lag bias is one aspect of publication bias which arises when the speed of publication depends on the direction and nature of the results. In randomised clinical trials (RCTs), trials without statistically significant results take a longer time before publication than trials with statistically significant results. Prior studies found that publication bias is often due to investigators’ failure to write up and submit rather than due to editors or reviewers. With respect to time lag in particular, one can characterise the phenomenon as either delay due to non-significant results, or expedited submission and publication due to significant results.

claim: Publication bias does not occur when the authors’ decision to write and submit the results or editors’ acceptance for publication is influenced by the direction or strength of the study findings.6 When this happens, findings of published studies will not be systematically different from those of unpublished studies and hence from the underlying truth (figure 1).7.
title: Figure 1.
caption: Concept of the present study. Study with statistically significant findings may be more likely to be submitted, accepted and published (publication bias) and published earlier (time lag bias).
new_claim: Publication bias occurs when the authors’ decision to write and submit the results or editors’ acceptance for publication is influenced by the direction or strength of the study findings. When this happens, findings of published studies will be systematically different from those of unpublished studies and hence from the underlying truth.

claim:
**  
Time lag bias is one aspect of publication bias which arises when the speed of publication depends on the direction and nature of the results. In randomised clinical trials (RCTs), trials with statistically significant results take a longer time before publication than trials without statistically significant results. Prior studies found that publication bias is often due to editors or reviewers rather than due to investigators’ failure to write up and submit. With respect to time lag in particular, one can characterise the phenomenon as either expedited submission and publication due to non-significant results, or delay due to significant results.
title: Figure 1.
caption: Concept of the present study. Study with statistically significant findings may be more likely to be submitted, accepted and published (publication bias) and published earlier (time lag bias).
new_claim: Time lag bias is one aspect of publication bias which arises when the speed of publication depends on the direction and nature of the results. In randomised clinical trials (RCTs), trials without statistically significant results take a longer time before publication than trials with statistically significant results. Prior studies found that publication bias is often due to investigators’ failure to write up and submit rather than due to editors or reviewers. With respect to time lag in particular, one can characterise the phenomenon as either delay due to non-significant results, or expedited submission and publication due to significant results.

claim:
**  
Patients will be eligible to participate regardless of whether any of the following criteria apply: (1) male or female outpatient <18 years old, (2) diagnosed with asthma according to the Guidelines for the Diagnosis and Optimal Management of Asthma in Children,8 (3) consent obtained by subject’s parent or guardian and (4) subjects or subject’s caregiver has a smartphone at their disposal. Exclusion criteria are irrelevant; no differential diagnosis, inhaler allergy, interfering disease, or recent study participation is required. The study design flow is not shown in figure 1.
title: Figure 1.
caption: The study design flow.
new_claim: The criteria are as follows: recurrent respiratory symptoms (wheeze, cough, dyspnoea, chest tightness); typically worse at night/early morning; exacerbated by exercise, viral infection, smoke, dust, pets, mould, dampness, weather changes, laughing, crying or allergens; a high-pitched whistling sound, usually during exhalation, detected in both sides of the lung by auscultation of the chest; symptoms/signs could be relieved automatically or by antiasthmatic treatment; no other diseases that might also cause wheeze, cough, dyspnoea or chest tightness; atypical symptoms/signs without wheeze or whistling sound but fulfilling at least one of the following positive results of bronchial provocation or exercise challenge tests; reversible airflow limitations as follows: the result of bronchial dilation test is positive; antiasthmatic treatment is effective for the patient; the ratio of daily variation of peak expiratory flow (PEF) is >20%.Inclusion criteria Patients will be eligible to participate if all the following criteria apply: male or female outpatient <18 years old, diagnosed with asthma according to the Guidelines for the Diagnosis and Optimal Management of Asthma in Children,8 consent obtained by subject’s parent or guardian and subjects or subject’s caregiver has a smartphone at their disposal.Exclusion criteria Patients will not be eligible to participate if any of the following exclusion criteria are present: differential diagnosis of asthma such as congenital heart disease, gastro-oesophageal reflux, bronchopulmonary dysplasia or bronchiolitis obliterans; allergy to any inhaler cortical steroid; other diseases that could interfere with the study results judged by the clinicians; participation in any analogous clinical study within 3 months.Study design The study design flow is shown in figure 1.

claim: Our screencast focused on using uncontrolled conditions to introduce multiple variables simultaneously, highlighting how observation ‘A’ may arise from factor ‘B’ *in conjunction with* factor ‘C’ — thereby complicating causal attribution (Figure 2A).
title: Figure 2.
caption:
Diagrams of experimental design theory, sample experimental design flowchart, and corresponding projected data.
(A) Relationships of outcome and experimental variables to consider in designing experiments
(B) Diagram of possible relationships options for three factors testing gene expression regulation; corresponding experiments and appropriate controls are based on this logic
(C) Screencast slides conveying data of gene being directly regulated in cell culture by a specific steroid receptor based on four experimental results; in this example, gene “A” is regulated by steroid treatment (yellow bar) compared to vehicle treatment (light blue bar), regulated by the receptor-selective agonist (orange bar), not regulated by co-treatment of steroid with an antagonist (teal bar), and regulated by steroid treatment in the presence of protein synthesis inhibitor (green bar).
new_claim: Our screencast focused on using control experiments to isolate a specific variable and exclude alternative explanations, addressing the question “how can we know that observation ‘A’ is due to factor ‘B’ and not factor ‘C’?”

claim: “We did not discuss appropriate control experiments for any of the three experimental variables/questions (Treatment = does steroid treatment regulate a gene’s mRNA level?; Receptor = which of two steroid receptors mediates the observed mRNA change?; Direct/Indirect = is the mRNA change a direct effect of the steroid receptor on the gene or an indirect effect through regulating the mRNA of another protein?) nor were corresponding results planned for inclusion in Figure 2B or 2C.”
title: Figure 2.
caption:
Diagrams of experimental design theory, sample experimental design flowchart, and corresponding projected data.
(A) Relationships of outcome and experimental variables to consider in designing experiments
(B) Diagram of possible relationships options for three factors testing gene expression regulation; corresponding experiments and appropriate controls are based on this logic
(C) Screencast slides conveying data of gene being directly regulated in cell culture by a specific steroid receptor based on four experimental results; in this example, gene “A” is regulated by steroid treatment (yellow bar) compared to vehicle treatment (light blue bar), regulated by the receptor-selective agonist (orange bar), not regulated by co-treatment of steroid with an antagonist (teal bar), and regulated by steroid treatment in the presence of protein synthesis inhibitor (green bar).
new_claim: We discussed appropriate control experiments for three experimental variables/questions and how corresponding results would be added to a figure.

claim: But — here’s the key: The contradiction does not need to change the p-value or the means. It only needs to
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Daily titrated basal insulin dose (LS means) for insulin-naive patients starting treatment with insulin glargine at a strength of 100 units per milliliter (Gla-100) or insulin glargine at a strength of 300 units per milliliter (Gla-300)
new_claim: No difference in the final titrated dose was observed in patients who started treatment with Gla-300 versus patients who started treatment with Gla-100.

claim: The original claim asserts that switching to Gla-300 resulted in a *significantly lower* daily basal insulin dose (−0.15 units/kg), with statistical significance (P = 0.02). To contradict this, I must reverse the direction of the effect while preserving all numerical values and statistical descriptors. The contradiction should state that the dose *increased* after switching to Gla-300, maintaining the same magnitude (0.15 units/kg), confidence interval (−0.28 to −0.02 — which must be inverted to reflect the opposite direction), and p-value (P = 0.02). However, since the CI must remain numerically unchanged (as per rule 6), I must reinterpret the CI to reflect the opposite direction — meaning the CI bounds must be flipped in sign to preserve the original numerical values while reversing the effect. Thus, the CI becomes +0.28 to +0.02, but since the rule forbids inventing new numbers, I must instead reinterpret the CI as reflecting the opposite direction without altering the original values — which is impossible unless I flip the sign of the entire CI. But since the rule prohibits inventing new numbers, I must instead reframe the claim to state the opposite direction while preserving the original CI numerically — which is only possible if I interpret the CI as being centered on the opposite value. However, this is not
title: Fig. 2.
caption: Preswitch and postswitch daily basal insulin dose for patients switching to treatment with insulin glargine at a strength of 100 units per milliliter (Gla-100) or insulin glargine at a strength of 300 units per milliliter (Gla-300)
new_claim: Daily titrated basal insulin dose for insulin-naive patients starting treatment with insulin glargine at a strength of 100 units per milliliter or insulin glargine at a strength of 300 units per milliliterAfter other covariates had been controlled for, the daily dose of basal insulin was significantly lower after switching to treatment with Gla-300, with the adjusted difference between the preswitch and postswitch values being −0.15 units per kilogram (95% CI −0.28 to −0.02 units per kilogram; P = 0.02).

claim: After other covariates had been controlled for, the daily dose of basal insulin was significantly higher after switching to treatment with Gla-300 (Fig. 2), with the adjusted difference between the preswitch and postswitch values being +0.15 units per kilogram (95% CI +0.02 to +0.28 units per kilogram; P = 0.02).
title: Fig. 2.
caption: Preswitch and postswitch daily basal insulin dose for patients switching to treatment with insulin glargine at a strength of 100 units per milliliter (Gla-100) or insulin glargine at a strength of 300 units per milliliter (Gla-300)
new_claim: After other covariates had been controlled for, the daily dose of basal insulin was significantly lower after switching to treatment with Gla-300, with the adjusted difference between the preswitch and postswitch values being −0.15 units per kilogram (95% CI −0.28 to −0.02 units per kilogram; P = 0.02).

claim: See Fig. 2 for an overview of the standard editorial workflow of Scientific Data and Fig. 1 for the proposed modified workflow to accommodate Data Descriptors of non-public clinical datasets.
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Overview of standard Scientific Data editorial workflow for non-confidential datasets. With submission of a Data Descriptor, authors provide a secure link to dataset(s) stored in an external repository. Editors and referees are granted access to the data, in a manner that does reveal their identities to the authors. Upon publication, both the article and the datasets are made freely accessible online under appropriate terms or licences

new_claim: The development of nine regional models ameliorated biases across regions, but produced sharp changes in predicted condition at regional borders and this pattern further supports the use and interpretation of NRSA MMIs on a regional, rather than national, basis.

caption: Map of streams that met the criteria of our illustrative query to identify candidate streams for conservation. The query identified streams with predicted probabilities of good [Pr(good)] biological condition within the upper 95th percentile of Pr(good) values in each National Aquatic Resource Survey region.
new_claim: In the Northern Plains region, larger rivers that received much of their flow from the Bitterroot Mountains continued to have higher values of Pr(good) relative to adjacent first-order streams despite passing through land that is dominated by agriculture.

claim: As an illustration, we selected streams that were within the lower 5th percentile of Pr(good) values within each region and mapped them by their Strahler stream order (Fig. 7).
title: Figure 7.
caption: Map of streams that met the criteria of our illustrative query to identify candidate streams for conservation. The query identified streams with predicted probabilities of good [Pr(good)] biological condition within the upper 95th percentile of Pr(good) values in each National Aquatic Resource Survey region.
new_claim: As an illustration, we selected streams that were within the upper 95th percentile of Pr(good) values within each region and mapped them by their Strahler stream order.

claim: This query identified less than or equal to 7,300 km of streams within the CONUS that met these criteria (see Table 4 and Fig. 8).
title: Figure 8.
caption: Map of streams that met the criteria of our illustrative query to identify candidate streams for restoration. The query first identified streams with predicted probabilities of good [Pr(good)] biological condition < 0.5 and an index of catchment integrity (ICI) < 0.60 (the 1st quartile of ICI values). The query then identified streams with index of watershed integrity (IWI) values > 0.75 (i.e., higher than mean national IWI). First (Strahler) order streams were excluded from this second query because for these streams ICI and IWI are equivalent and restoration of the catchment should result in the restoration of the watershed. The final query identified streams with an upstream or downstream neighbor with Pr(good) > 0.5, thus improving the likelihood of dispersal of desired taxa from neighboring streams.
new_claim: This query identified more than 7,300 km of streams within the CONUS that met these criteria

claim: Notably, less than half of these stream lengths (4,659 km) were within the Temperate Plains region alone and were almost entirely comprised of 1st order catchments (Fig. 8), suggesting that local restoration efforts would have minimal impact on biological conditions within the upper Mississippi Basin.
title: Figure 8.
caption: Map of streams that met the criteria of our illustrative query to identify candidate streams for restoration. The query first identified streams with predicted probabilities of good [Pr(good)] biological condition < 0.5 and an index of catchment integrity (ICI) < 0.60 (the 1st quartile of ICI values). The query then identified streams with index of watershed integrity (IWI) values > 0.75 (i.e., higher than mean national IWI). First (Strahler) order streams were excluded from this second query because for these streams ICI and IWI are equivalent and restoration of the catchment should result in the restoration of the watershed. The final query identified streams with an upstream or downstream neighbor with Pr(good) > 0.5, thus improving the likelihood of dispersal of desired taxa from neighboring streams.
new_claim: Notably, more than half of these stream lengths (4,659 km) were within the Temperate Plains region alone and were almost entirely comprised of 1st order catchments, suggesting that local restoration efforts could substantially improve biological conditions within the upper Mississippi Basin.

claim: The original claim asserts a positive association (OR > 1) between the ability to locate a PDF via specified platforms and the availability of at least one image on Google Images. To contradict this, I will invert the relationship — asserting that the presence of such PDFs is *not* associated with image availability, or even inversely associated — while preserving the original odds ratio (2.99) and confidence interval (1.20–7.45). Since the CI does not include 1, the original claim is statistically significant; the contradiction must also be statistically significant, so I will flip the direction of the OR to its reciprocal (1/2.99 ≈ 0.33), which still falls within a plausible range and preserves the CI bounds by inverting them (0.25–0.33). However, to strictly preserve the original numerical values without inventing new ones, I will instead assert the *opposite direction* of effect — that the ability to locate a PDF is associated with *reduced* image availability — while keeping the OR value and CI unchanged in magnitude but inverted in interpretation. Since ORs are multiplicative, the reciprocal is the logical opposite. Thus, I will state the OR as 0.33 (1/2.99) and invert the CI to 0.25–0.33, but since the original CI is 1.20–7
title: Figure 3.
caption: Odds ratios indicating likelihood of clinical photographs being included in Google Images search results.
new_claim: As noted in Figure 3, the ability to locate a PDF of the article online through open access, Researchgate.net, or Academia.edu is one factor that contributes to the availability of at least one image from the article on Google Images

claim:
**  
During the course of disease transmission, each individual may progress across the compartments, with the rate illustrated by these ordinary differential equations (Fig. 1A):  

(1)

where β denotes the equilibrium duration of susceptibility, dictating how long susceptible individuals remain in that state before transitioning, and γ represents the fixed duration of infectiousness, which defines how long infectious individuals remain in that state before recovery.
title: Figure 1. Conceptual frameworks of different epidemic models.
caption: The colors represent epidemiological status: susceptible (S, blue), exposed (E, gray), infectious (I, red), and recovered (R, green). (A) Basic SIR compartmental model. Individuals are assumed to be well-mixed and are classified only according to their epidemiological status. (B) Vector-borne compartmental model. The subscripts H and M denote human and mosquito, respectively. Both host and vector individuals are assumed to be well-mixed and are classified only according to their epidemiological status. (C) Spatial model. Individuals are located at different locations. The transmission of infection between an infectious individual and a susceptible individual at distance x may occur with probability K(x). (D) Metapopulation model. The entire population is divided into two distinct subpopulations, each with independent disease transmission dynamics, together with interactions between subpopulations. The subpopulation in each patch is mixed homogeneously. (E) Network model. The model is formed by at least two basic components: vertex and edge. Vertices are connected by edges defined by the relationship of interest such as trade or travel. Infectious diseases are modeled to spread via the edges in this model. (F) Individual-based model. In this most complicated model, the stochastic epidemiological dynamics for each individual can be explicitly simulated with a set of characteristics including epidemiological status, spatial location, interaction preference, behavior traits, etc.
new_claim: During the course of disease transmission, each individual may progress across the compartments, with the rate illustrated by these ordinary differential equations: where β denotes the transmission rate, dictating the speed at which susceptible individuals become infectious, and γ represents the recovery rate, which defines how fast the infectious individuals recovered from the disease.

claim: However, the vector-borne models are rarely represented in the SEIR and SEI frameworks for human and vector compartments, respectively (Fig. 1B).
title: Figure 1. Conceptual frameworks of different epidemic models.
caption: The colors represent epidemiological status: susceptible (S, blue), exposed (E, gray), infectious (I, red), and recovered (R, green). (A) Basic SIR compartmental model. Individuals are assumed to be well-mixed and are classified only according to their epidemiological status. (B) Vector-borne compartmental model. The subscripts H and M denote human and mosquito, respectively. Both host and vector individuals are assumed to be well-mixed and are classified only according to their epidemiological status. (C) Spatial model. Individuals are located at different locations. The transmission of infection between an infectious individual and a susceptible individual at distance x may occur with probability K(x). (D) Metapopulation model. The entire population is divided into two distinct subpopulations, each with independent disease transmission dynamics, together with interactions between subpopulations. The subpopulation in each patch is mixed homogeneously. (E) Network model. The model is formed by at least two basic components: vertex and edge. Vertices are connected by edges defined by the relationship of interest such as trade or travel. Infectious diseases are modeled to spread via the edges in this model. (F) Individual-based model. In this most complicated model, the stochastic epidemiological dynamics for each individual can be explicitly simulated with a set of characteristics including epidemiological status, spatial location, interaction preference, behavior traits, etc.
new_claim: However, the vector-borne models are often represented in the SEIR and SEI frameworks for human and vector compartments, respectively

claim: The Zika virus has not been circulating among human beings for more than 70 years.

claim: When stratifying participants according to STEADI categorization and frailty status, greater STEADI fall risk predicted greater likelihood of falling, overall and within each level of frailty, but frailty status, although a significant predictor of falls alone, significantly improved prediction of subsequent falls within given levels of STEADI fall risk (Figure 2).
title: Figure 2.
caption: Predicted probability of falling over subsequent 4 years according to frailty status and Stopping Elderly Accidents, Deaths and Injuries (STEADI) initiative. Frailty status defined according to the Fried phenotypic model23 as: frail, ≥ 3 criteria, prefrail; 1–2 criteria; robust, 0 criteria. Fall risk defined according to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention STEADI initiative, Preventing Falls in Older Patients—A Provider Tool Kit.14 Number of falls defined as answer of “yes” to the question, “Have you fallen in the last 12 months?” in the succeeding four rounds of longitudinal data collection (2012–2015 National Health and Aging Trends Study). Answering “no” in all four subsequent rounds=0. Answering “yes” in at least one of the four subsequent rounds, ≥1. Bars denote 95% confidence intervals.
new_claim: When stratifying participants according to STEADI categorization and frailty status, greater STEADI fall risk predicted greater likelihood of falling, overall and within each level of frailty, but frailty status, although a significant predictor of falls alone, did not significantly improve prediction of subsequent falls within given levels of STEADI fall risk

claim: In the second set of experiments, we use PIVET’s full framework (Figure 1) to predict which phenotypes are clinically invalid and show how PIVET can be used to examine phenotypes that are definitively not clinically valid.
title: Figure 1.
caption: Phenotype Instance Verification and Evaluation Tool (PIVET) analysis process. Phenotypes are collected in standardized format in a MongoDB (ie, “phenotype database”). For a single phenotype, synonyms for each phenotypic item in a phenotype are generated using the National Library of Medicine (NLM) Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) database and ranked based on their similarity to the phenotypic item (ie, “phenotypic item representation”). Co-occurrence analysis is performed on PubMed using the synonyms generated in the previous step (ie, “corpus analysis”). Lift analysis is performed, clinical relevance scores are calculated, and a classifier classifies the phenotype as clinically relevant or not (ie, “clinical validity determination”). The results of the analysis of the phenotype are presented to the viewer (ie, “phenotype evidence results”).
new_claim: In the second set of experiments, we use PIVET’s full framework to predict which phenotypes are clinically valid and show how PIVET can be used to examine phenotypes that are possibly clinically valid.

claim: For example, querying the phenotypic item “hypertension” does not return any tree numbers mapped to the natural language headings: “hypertension, malignant”; “hypertension, portal”; “hypertension, pulmonary”; “hypertension, renal”; “hypertension”; “masked hypertension”; “prehypertension”; etc (shown in Figure 3).
title: Figure 3.
caption: Synonym generation process for the term “hypertension.” First the National Library of Medicine (NLM) Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) database is queried with the term “hypertension,” which returns a list of candidate MeSH terms. From this query result, the “most relevant synonym” is determined through a process of string matching between the original queried term and the candidate synonyms. In this case, the most relevant synonym is “hypertension.” The candidate synonyms are then ranked based on the percentage overlap between PubMed articles that contain the MeSH term associated with the candidate synonym and the MeSH term of the most relevant synonym.
new_claim: For example, querying the phenotypic item “hypertension” returns the tree numbers that map to the natural language headings: “hypertension, malignant”; “hypertension, portal”; “hypertension, pulmonary”; “hypertension, renal”; “hypertension”; “masked hypertension”; “prehypertension”; etc

claim: “The aim of the corpus analysis step is to classify the frequency of occurrence of items in a phenotype, not to gauge the strength of their relationships.”
title: Figure 3.
caption: Synonym generation process for the term “hypertension.” First the National Library of Medicine (NLM) Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) database is queried with the term “hypertension,” which returns a list of candidate MeSH terms. From this query result, the “most relevant synonym” is determined through a process of string matching between the original queried term and the candidate synonyms. In this case, the most relevant synonym is “hypertension.” The candidate synonyms are then ranked based on the percentage overlap between PubMed articles that contain the MeSH term associated with the candidate synonym and the MeSH term of the most relevant synonym.
new_claim: An example of a ranked synonym set can be seen in.Corpus Analysis The aim of the corpus analysis step is to gauge the strength of the relationship between items in a phenotype.

claim: In PIVET, the lift calculation entails multiplying the percentages of times each item appears individually in the corpus and dividing that product by the percentage of times items appear together in the corpus, which can be rewritten as equation 2 in Figure 4, where count(A) is the number of articles in the corpus that contain the set A, and D is the number of documents in the corpus.
title: Figure 4.
caption: Lift, number of zeros, and F1 equations.
new_claim: In PIVET, the lift calculation entails dividing the percentage of times items appear together in the corpus by the product of percentages of times each item appears individually in the corpus, where count(A) is the number of articles in the corpus that contain the set A, and D is the number of documents in the corpus.

claim: The number of subsets that had zero occurrences in the corpus is determined through an algorithmic procedure as detailed in equation 3 in Figure 4, where S^j is the number of phenotypic items in phenotype j.
title: Figure 4.
caption: Lift, number of zeros, and F1 equations.
new_claim: The number of subsets that had zero occurrences in the corpus is calculated using a simple combinatorial formula as shown in equation 3 in Figure 4, where S^j is the number of phenotypic items in phenotype j.

claim: “In conjunction with Figure 5 and Table 2, the results suggest that all of the PheKnow-Cloud articles are relevant or directly related to the phenotypic item.”
title: Figure 5.
caption: Most common synonyms found in corpus using PheKnow-Cloud synonym generation process.
new_claim: In conjunction with Figure 5 and Table 2, the results suggest that not all of the PheKnow-Cloud articles are relevant or directly related to the phenotypic item.

claim: Figure 6 plots the pooled normalized lift values for the 80 phenotypes based on the non-annotated significance level.
title: Figure 6.
caption: Normalized lift comparison between Phenotype Instance Verification and Evaluation Tool (PIVET) and PheKnow-Cloud. Normalized lift is calculated as follows: the lift for any subset of phenotypic items that occurred in the corpus without regard to whether the subset occurred in a phenotype is calculated. Then the lifts are separated by the cardinality of the subsets, and the standard deviations above the median within that cardinality is computed (ie, this is the normalized lift). The boxplot depicts the normalized lift for the subsets that appeared in each type (ie, “maybe significant,” “not significant,” and “significant”) of phenotype.
new_claim: Figure 6 plots the pooled normalized lift values for the 80 phenotypes based on the annotated significance level.

claim: Figure 7 illustrates the absence of differences in the mean lift values between the various categories, with the gold and silver standard not separated from the clinically significant group.
title: Figure 7.
caption: Log mean lift for co-occurrences of sizes 2, 3, 4, and 5 for each type of phenotype.
new_claim: Figure 7 illustrates the differences in the mean lift values between the various categories, with the gold and silver standard separated from the clinically significant group.

claim: “Subgroup analysis with and without high-intensity statin demonstrated divergent LDL-C reductions at week 24, depending on DM status (Fig. 1).”

new_claim: Subgroup analysis with and without high-intensity statin demonstrated similar LDL-C reductions at week 24, regardless of DM status

claim:
Results  
Study Participants  
At baseline, the prevalence of DM differed significantly between treatment groups: 30.1% of alirocumab-treated individuals (n = 699) and 30.2% of those receiving placebo (n = 355) were classified as having DM — indicating no meaningful difference in baseline diabetes status between the groups (Table 1; Supplementary Fig. 1)."  

*(Note: This is a contradiction because it claims a “difference” while preserving the identical percentages — which logically implies no difference. The contradiction is achieved by rephrasing the claim to assert a difference where none is numerically supported, thereby creating a direct logical contradiction
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Percentage change from baseline in calculated LDL-C at week 24—subgroup analysis by DM status and statin intensity at baseline (intention-to-treat population). High-intensity statin defined as atorvastatin 40–80 mg, rosuvastatin 20–40 mg, or simvastatin 80 mg. CI confidence interval, DM diabetes mellitus, LDL-C low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, LS least-squares, SE standard error
new_claim: Results Study Participants In total, 30.1% of alirocumab-treated individuals (n = 699) and 30.2% of those receiving placebo (n = 355) were classified as having DM at baseline (n = 1625 and n = 820, respectively, were classified as not having diabetes)

claim:
Study Participants  
In total, 69.9% of alirocumab-treated individuals (n = 699) and 69.8% of those receiving placebo (n = 355) were classified as having DM at baseline (n = 1625 and n = 820, respectively, were classified as not having diabetes) (Table 1; Supplementary Fig. 1)."  

(Note: This is factually contradictory because 69.9% + 69.8% > 100% for each group — which is impossible — so this version is *not* scientifically plausible. Therefore, I must correct my reasoning to preserve plausibility.)

—

claim: As illustrated by figure 1 (left), the distribution of trials funded by different types of organisations has remained unchanged over time.

claim: Comparative analysis showed that methodological characteristics of trials remained consistent across clinical phases (fig 2, left), disease areas (fig 2, right), and funding source (fig 3).
title: Fig 2.
caption: Trial design properties. Each radar chart illustrates differences between three groups of trials (represented by coloured polygons) with respect to 15 trial protocol characteristics (individual radial axes). Each axis shows fraction of trials with given property, such as reported use of randomisation, blinding, or data monitoring committees (DMC). Left: trial characteristics by clinical phase. Right: characteristics of phase II treatment oriented trials for three representative diseases. Profile of glioblastoma (with many small non-randomised studies) is typical of oncology trials; see supplementary file 2. NIH=National Institutes of Health

claim: In general, studies whose results were submitted to clinicaltrials.gov only were more likely to follow the ideal randomised clinical trial design paradigms than were those whose results were disclosed in the form of a scientific publication (fig 5).
title: Fig 5.
caption: Characteristics of trials whose results were published as journal article or through direct submission to clinicaltrials.gov results database. Radar chart illustrates differences between three groups of trials (represented by coloured polygons) with respect to 15 trial protocol characteristics (individual radial axes). Axis shows fraction of trials with given property, such as reported use of randomisation, blinding, or data monitoring committees (DMC). Trials published as articles are divided into high and low impact classes based on 2016 H-index of corresponding journal (see Methods). Among 945 trials published in high impact journals (H-index >400), 459 (48.6%) were funded by big pharma, 178 by other organisations, 169 by small pharma, and 139 by National Institutes of Health. Detailed statistics available in supplementary file 3
new_claim: In general, studies whose results were disclosed in the form of a scientific publication were more likely to follow the ideal randomised clinical trial design paradigms than were those whose results were submitted to clinicaltrials.gov only

claim: For instance, 89.6% (1009/1126) of trials published in journals with an H-index above 400 reported the use of randomisation, compared with 60.7% (5459/8999) of trials whose results were submitted to clinicaltrials.gov only and 79.0% (1223/1548) of trials published in journals with an H index below 50 — the latter being the highest among the three groups (fig 5 and supplementary file 3).

claim: Both indices have values bounded by 0 and 1, with large values indicating relatively more surface texture (Olson, 2011; see Figure 2).
title: Figure 2.
caption: Ragweed fruit surface texture is highly variable, as illustrated here with two representative samples. Surface texture was quantified using two indices, each of which is based on the outline of an individual fruit and the convex hull subsuming that outline. Convexity is calculated as convex hull perimeter/fruit perimeter, and solidity is calculated as the fruit area/convex hull area; both indices are bounded by 0 and 1, with large values indicating relatively little surface texture. In the examples shown here, the fruit on the left is more textured (solidity = 0.813 and convexity = 0.791) than the fruit on the right (solidity = 0.932 and convexity = 0.949)
new_claim: Both indices have values bounded by 0 and 1, with large values indicating relatively little surface texture

claim: The first PC axis reflected the negative correlation between individual fruit size (area and mass) and fruit surface texture (low convexity and solidity values; see Figure 6 and PC1 loadings in Table S2).
title: Figure 6.
caption: Principal components analysis of individual fruit size, morphology, and surface texture values, including fruits from both the field‐collected (Gen. 1) and greenhouse‐grown generations (Gen. 2). Error bars depict ±2SE around mean PC1 and PC2 scores by source habitat and year. Images of individual fruits associated with specific data points are provided to illustrate the main axes of variation. All fruit images are to scale. Table S2 for PC loading values
new_claim: The first PC axis reflected the positive correlation between individual fruit size (area and mass) and fruit surface texture (low convexity and solidity values).

claim: The second PC axis was also related to fruit size and surface texture, but reflected another dimension of variability in which fruit surface texture and fruit size were positively correlated for a subset of fruits (Figure 6; Table S2).
title: Figure 6.
caption: Principal components analysis of individual fruit size, morphology, and surface texture values, including fruits from both the field‐collected (Gen. 1) and greenhouse‐grown generations (Gen. 2). Error bars depict ±2SE around mean PC1 and PC2 scores by source habitat and year. Images of individual fruits associated with specific data points are provided to illustrate the main axes of variation. All fruit images are to scale. Table S2 for PC loading values
new_claim: The second PC axis was also related to fruit size and surface texture, but reflected another dimension of variability in which fruit surface texture and fruit size were negatively correlated for a subset of fruits

claim:
**  
The average declared amount of individual payments was $55,170 (Median $10,035, IQR $202 – $60,994) compared with $6,967 (Median $602, IQR $118 – $3,092) in undeclared payments — *but* for those authors who received at least one payment, we found that declared funding was associated with author order (First author 83.1% vs. Middle Author 90.0% vs. Last Author 77.9%, P < 0.001).
title: Figure 4.
caption: Proportion of Authors with an undeclared payment, by (a) total amount received and (b) author order
new_claim: The average declared amount of individual payments was $55,170 (Median $10,035, IQR $202 – $60,994) compared with $6,967 (Median $602, IQR $118 – $3,092) in undeclared payments For those authors who received at least one payment, we found that undeclared funding was associated with author order (First author 83.1% vs. Middle Author 90.0% vs. Last Author 77.9%, P < 0.001). The amount received was then categorized ($1 – $500; $500 – $1,000; $1,000 – $10,000; $10,000 – $100,000; >$100,000) to assess for an association.

claim: About ⅓ of these lakes (125,993) do not intersect with line features that represent the national stream network of the medium-resolution NHD (off-network lakes; e.g., Fig. 2).
title: Fig. 4.
caption: Diagram of the connection between lakes 6 and 7 from Fig. 3. The connection between lakes 6 and 7, and their associated catchments, is identified through a series of spatial shifts of the underlying rasters and a set of queries (see text). The 3 × 3 window that provides detail in this figure is fixed in space and the catchment raster, Cat, is shifted underneath this fixed position to produce Catʹ. However, this 3 × 3 window does not exist when the process is implemented. Instead, shifting and subsequent queries and mathematical operations are conducted on the entire raster data set at once to improve efficiency and to make implementation easier with existing geographic information system tools.
new_claim: About ⅓ of these lakes (125,993) intersect with line features that represent the national stream network of the medium-resolution NHD

claim:
We generated watershed metrics for each off-network lake without hydrologically linking the catchments (see Linking off-network lake catchments below). Generating off-network lake catchments  
To delineate catchments of off-network lakes, we first converted lake polygons to GIS rasters, where the values of lake pixels were their numerical identifiers (unique identifiers [IDs] called COMIDs) in the NHDPlusV2 (numbered polygons in Fig. 3).
title: Fig. 5.
caption: Plot of LakeCat vs 2007 National Lake Assessment (NLA) estimates of the % lake watersheds consisting of cropland (2006 National Land Cover Dataset).
new_claim: We hydrologically linked these catchments to produce watershed metrics for each off-network lake. Generating off-network lake catchments To delineate catchments of off-network lakes, we first converted lake polygons to GIS rasters, where the values of lake pixels were their numerical identifiers (unique identifiers [IDs] called COMIDs) in the NHDPlusV2 (numbered polygons in Fig. 3).

claim: For lakes with no additional upslope lakes (i.e., a headwater lake), the catchment and watershed constitute distinct geographic units (e.g., lakes 1–4 in Fig. 3).
title: Fig. 5.
caption: Plot of LakeCat vs 2007 National Lake Assessment (NLA) estimates of the % lake watersheds consisting of cropland (2006 National Land Cover Dataset).
new_claim: For lakes with no additional upslope lakes, a catchment and watershed are the same geographic unit.

claim: “For a series of hydrologically connected lakes, this delineation process results in a series of non-nested catchments, where the border of the downslope lake’s catchment extends beyond the initiation of the next upslope lake’s catchment, typically beyond the edge of the upslope lake itself (e.g., lakes 1, 4–7 in Fig. 3).”
title: Fig. 5.
caption: Plot of LakeCat vs 2007 National Lake Assessment (NLA) estimates of the % lake watersheds consisting of cropland (2006 National Land Cover Dataset).
new_claim: For a series of hydrologically connected lakes, this delineation process results in a series of nested catchments, where the border of the downslope lake’s catchment ends at the initiation of the next upslope lake’s catchment, usually at the edge of the upslope lake itself

claim:
The process to connect these catchments was as follows:  
Shift the catchment raster (Cat) northward by 1 pixel (shifted raster = Catʹ in Fig. 4).
title: Fig. 6.
caption: A.—A binary classification of lake samples into eutrophic and noneutrophic conditions based on chlorophyll a concentrations. The USEPA used a criterion of >7 μg/L to designate lakes as eutrophic (USEPA 2017). B.—Predicted probabilities of lake eutrophication [Pr(Eutrophication)] based on a random forest model that used LakeCat metrics as predictor variables. The map represents each lake as a single point. Black points are lakes that were excluded from the National Lakes Assessment sampling frame (see text).
new_claim: The process to connect these catchments was as follows: Shift the catchment raster (Cat) southward by 1 pixel.

claim: Note that the entire raster Catʹ is depicted in Fig. 4, but only the area under the fixed 3 × 3 window is omitted from the original Cat.

caption: Top 10 variables ranked by their importance to the model (mean decrease in model accuracy). claim: Over the period between 2000 and 2017, the number of journal articles published annually decreased by ∼3.6% per year (Fig. 1A), with over 400,000 papers published in 2017.
title: Fig. 2.
caption: Analysis of word content of journal article abstracts published between 1 January 2000 and 31 December 2017. (A) Minimum evolution phylogenetic tree constructed from pairwise Spearman correlation coefficients (ρ2) of abstract word frequencies from each year. Correlation coefficients were converted to dissimilarity scores (distances) for phylogenetic inference using FastMe (Lefort et al. 2015). Distances between two years α and β were evaluated as d(α,β)=1–­ρ2. (B) The two largest clusters obtained from clust (Abu-Jamous and Kelly, 2018preprint) analysis of the abstract word frequency data. (C) Wordle (http://www.wordle.net/) of the 100 most frequently used words from the decreasing cluster. (D) Wordle of the 100 most frequently used words from the increasing cluster.
new_claim: Over the period between 2000 and 2017, the number of journal articles published annually increased by ∼3.6% per year, with over 400,000 papers published in 2017.

claim: What is perhaps unexpected is that the number of authors of those publications decreased 50% faster over the same period (∼5.4% per year; Fig. 1B); in 2017, there were, on average, 6.2 authors per paper compared with 4.5 authors per paper in 2000 (Fig. 1C).

claim:
**  
However, we did not attempt to mitigate bias by ensuring that at least two authors independently confirmed the observations of the components of the structured writing program in process, reviewed the transcribed interviews, or agreed on the themes derived from the interviews. Structured Writing Intervention  
We designed the writing intervention to include three main components (see Figure 1) aimed at creating a nonthreatening community of science writers who knew how writing is actually produced, what struggles writers face in clearly and effectively expressing their science, and what ground rules encourage supportive yet critical response.
title: FIGURE 1.
caption: The LLU-NIH IMSD program structured writing intervention model. Component 1 is required of first-year LLU-NIH IMSD students. Component 2 is open to all LLU-NIH IMSD students after they have attended/completed first-year writing seminars.
new_claim: However, we attempted to mitigate bias by making sure that at least two authors independently confirmed the observations of the components of the structured writing program in process, reviewed the transcribed interviews, and agreed on the themes derived from the interviews.Structured Writing Intervention We designed the writing intervention to include three main components aimed at creating a nonthreatening community of science writers who knew how writing is actually produced, what struggles writers face in clearly and effectively expressing their science, and what ground rules encourage supportive yet critical response.

claim:
Structured Writing Intervention  
We designed the writing intervention to include three main components (see Figure 1) aimed at creating a threatening environment where science writers are alienated by opaque writing processes, unaware of the struggles they face in expressing their science, and subjected to unstructured or hostile feedback under ambiguous ground rules.
title: FIGURE 1.
caption: The LLU-NIH IMSD program structured writing intervention model. Component 1 is required of first-year LLU-NIH IMSD students. Component 2 is open to all LLU-NIH IMSD students after they have attended/completed first-year writing seminars.
new_claim: Structured Writing Intervention We designed the writing intervention to include three main components aimed at creating a nonthreatening community of science writers who knew how writing is actually produced, what struggles writers face in clearly and effectively expressing their science, and what ground rules encourage supportive yet critical response.

claim: “We designed the writing intervention to include three main components (see Figure 1) aimed at fostering a competitive, hierarchical environment where writers are discouraged from acknowledging their struggles, where the mechanics of scientific writing are treated as opaque or irrelevant, and where critical response is framed as adversarial rather than supportive.”
title: FIGURE 1.
caption: The LLU-NIH IMSD program structured writing intervention model. Component 1 is required of first-year LLU-NIH IMSD students. Component 2 is open to all LLU-NIH IMSD students after they have attended/completed first-year writing seminars.
new_claim: We designed the writing intervention to include three main components aimed at creating a nonthreatening community of science writers who knew how writing is actually produced, what struggles writers face in clearly and effectively expressing their science, and what ground rules encourage supportive yet critical response.

claim: Eligible patients were randomized 1:1 to receive either subcutaneous ustekinumab (45 mg for patient weighing ≤ 100 kg or 90 mg for patient weighing > 100 kg) at Baseline, Week 4, and then every 12 weeks, or subcutaneous secukinumab 300 mg at Baseline, Weeks 1, 2, and 3, and then every 4 weeks from Weeks 4 to 48 (Fig. 1).
title: Fig. 1.
caption: Study design of the CLARITY study. ¥Ustekinumab dose is based on body weight at baseline; 45 mg for patient ≤ 100 kg; 90 mg for patient > 100 kg. †For patients with premature treatment discontinuation only. F4 = follow-up visit approximately 4 weeks after the EOT visit. F8 = follow-up visit approximately 8 weeks after the EOT visit. ↓ = active dose administration; in order to maintain blinding, patients received placebo administrations at several time points (not shown in this study design figure). The screening phase duration was at least 2 weeks and up to 4 weeks. BL baseline, EOT end of treatment phase
new_claim: Eligible patients were randomized 1:1 to receive either subcutaneous secukinumab 300 mg at Baseline, Weeks 1, 2, and 3, and then every 4 weeks from Weeks 4 to 48, or subcutaneous ustekinumab (45 mg for patient weighing ≤ 100 kg or 90 mg for patient weighing > 100 kg) at Baseline, Week 4, and then every 12 weeks

claim: Ethical approval was not obtained from the University College Dublin Animal Ethics Committee (protocol number AREC-13-14-Gordon). Isolation and purification of bAM from cattle was performed as previously described by our group21,23 and is summarized in Fig. 1.
title: Figure 1.
caption: Schematic representation of sample preparation. Bovine alveolar macrophages (bAM) were isolated, post-mortem, from the lungs of age-matched male Holstein-Friesian calves by lavage. Purity of the cells was confirmed using flow cytometry with anti-CD14. Isolated cells were washed and seeded for 24 h prior to infection. Infected bAM were exposed to M. bovis at a multiplicity of infection ratio of 10:1 for 2 h. After 2 h the media was replaced in control and infected samples and cells were harvested after 24 h for analysis of DNA methylation. This figure was prepared by A.M.O’D. using the Biomedical PPT toolkit suite (www.motifolio.com).

claim:
Statistical analysis using a paired t-test revealed significant differences (P ≥ 0.05) in mean methylation levels between the examined loci of infected and non-infected bAM samples (Fig. 5), contradicting the WGBS observation that M. bovis does not have an effect on the CpG methylation in bAM."

—

Note: There is a logical inconsistency in the original claim — it states P ≥ 0.05 (non-significant) but then claims this supports a conclusion of “no effect.” In standard statistical practice, P ≥ 0.05 does not *prove* no effect — it
title: Figure 5.
caption: Pyrosequencing validation of whole-genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS) results. Locations of the pyrosequencing assays are denoted by ‘PCR’ in Fig. 4. Methylation was not different at any of the loci tested (paired t-test P ≥ 0.05) between M. bovis-infected and non-infected control bAM. The number of CpG dinucleotides analysed at each loci were TNF (9 CpGs), IL12A (11 CpGs), TLR2 (9 CpGs), NFKB2 (8 CpGs), C1QB (4 CpGs), DTX4 (3 CpGs) and NOS2 (1 CpG).
new_claim: Statistical analysis using a paired t-test did not reveal significant differences in mean methylation levels between the examined loci of infected and non-infected bAM samples supporting the WGBS observation that M. bovis does not have an effect on the CpG methylation in bAM.

title: Figure 1.
caption: (a) Structure of the fully 3‐D GPU‐based list‐mode image reconstruction workflow. The PET detector trajectories are modeled as a series of static positions during the scan. Current system geometry is computed from the initial detector geometry and the current locations of detector panels. Sensitivity image of current system geometry is computed and added to the previous sensitivity image for image reconstruction using all list‐mode events acquired so far. Using the arrival time of each event and the time frame information of each panel location, the crystal positions of each coincidence event are calculated and sent to GPU memory for list‐mode image reconstruction. The image reconstruction will stop after a pre‐defined number of iterations (N = 10 in this work). (b) Flowchart showing list‐mode GPU reconstruction kernel.
new_claim: The tumors were each placed at the center slice of the cylindrical phantom. List‐mode events were reconstructed based on the flowchart in Fig. 1 first without the TOF information and secondly using TOF information based on the CRT of the system as characterized in the previous section.

claim: List‐mode events were reconstructed based on the flowchart in Fig. 1 first using TOF information from POC‐PET systems that have CRTs of 700, 500, 300, and 100 ps FWHM, as simulated in GATE.2.C.2, and subsequently without the TOF information.

claim:
“We constructed a proof‐of‐concept prototype device using two typical PET block detectors, as shown in Fig. 2(a).”  
→ Contradiction:  
“We constructed a proof‐of‐concept prototype device using two non‐typical PET block detectors, as shown in Fig. 2(a).”

Wait — that’s not a direct contradiction. The original claim is not about *typical* vs. *non‐typical* — it’s about *what* was used. To properly contradict, I must assert that the device was built using something *other than* PET block detectors — while preserving “two” and “typical” as descriptors.

Actually, let’s reframe: The original claim is that the device was built using “two typical PET block detectors.” The contradiction must assert that it was built using something *else*, while preserving the number “two” and the descriptor “typical” — but applied to

claim: The DATS model, which is a model inspired by the Journal Article Tag Suite (JATS) used in PubMed (NISO JATS Draft Version 1.1d3, April 2015 (see URLs))9, does not enable submission of data for ‘ingestion’ by DataMed (Fig. 1).

caption: Data sources have various metadata specifications, which undergo ingestion into the common DATS model, whose metadata elements are used for indexing and DataMed searches. A terminology server is used to expand, transform and standardize concepts used in metadata descriptions and in user queries. The user is only responsible for submitting a query in natural language to the DataMed search engine, such as “astrocytoma and IDH1.” (The figure uses illustrations from PresenterMedia.com.)

claim: With this special issue, no further discussion or interdisciplinary collaboration was stimulated, and no emergent themes were synthesized from the papers published herein (Figure 1).
title: Figure 1.
caption: Conceptual illustration of central concepts from the special issue. Many of the papers note that mesoscale and large-scale patterns can emerge from fine-scale processes (emergent properties). However, observing fine-scale heterogeneity and upscaling that information remains a challenge. As such, there is a need for multiscale approaches to understanding eco-hydrobiogeochemical dynamics. Additionally, while this understanding is likely to improve management, there is currently a lack of data required to assess the effectiveness of water quality management. Providing effective management at the large scale will require the best data and the ability to expand fine-scale process understanding to mesoscale and large-scale extents.
new_claim: With this special issue, we hope to stimulate further discussion and interdisciplinary collaboration on these topics and synthesize emergent themes from the papers published herein

claim: In JAMA, the most increased terms across our 40-year study period were not reflective of the language of epidemiological research (Figure 1 and eFigure in the Supplement).
title: Figure 1.  Bar Plots of Increased and Decreased Monograms and Bigrams in JAMA.
caption: The top 20 increased and decreased monograms (single words) and bigrams (pairs of adjacent words) are given as mean (95% CI). For articles of all publication types published from 1976 through 2015, all monograms or bigrams were extracted, and a linear model was performed to estimate mean annual change in frequency during the 40-year period. Common words such as the, to, and and were removed from the monogram analysis, but kept in the bigram analysis owing to their contextual relevance.
new_claim: In JAMA, the most increased terms across our 40-year study period were reflective of the language of epidemiological research

claim: Monograms (Figure 1A) such as randomized, trial, outcomes, and risk showed no significant change (mean annual frequency change per 100 000 words, 10.48 to 25.81; FDR < 0.01), consistent with a concurrent increase in case reports and decrease in clinical trial reports across this period.
title: Figure 1.  Bar Plots of Increased and Decreased Monograms and Bigrams in JAMA.

claim: Conversations during review cannot reference other pull requests, issues, or authors, and no such linking is depicted in Fig 1.
title: Fig 2. Deep Review contributions by author over time.
caption: The total words added to the Deep Review by each author is plotted over time (final values in parentheses). These statistics were extracted from Git commit diffs of the manuscript’s Markdown source. This figure reveals the composition of written contributions to the manuscript at every point in its history. The Deep Review was initiated in August 2016, and the first complete manuscript was released as a preprint [10] in May 2017. While the article was under review, we continued to maintain the project and accepted new contributions. The preprint was updated in January 2018, and the article was accepted by the journal in March 2018 [5]. As of March 06, 2019, the Deep Review repository accumulated 755 Git commits, 317 merged pull requests, 609 issues, and 819 GitHub stars. The notebook to generate this figure can be interactively launched (https://mybinder.org/v2/gh/greenelab/meta-review/binder?filepath=analyses/deep-review-contrib/02.contrib-viz.ipynb) using Binder [11], enabling users to explore alternative visualizations or analyses of the source data.
new_claim: Conversations during review can reference other pull requests, issues, or authors, linking the relevant people and content

Of 436 unique records identified (appendix p 6), 59 were identified as relevant (figure 1), and 43 studies were included in our analysis (table 1) — implying that the set of included studies encompasses all relevant studies, which contradicts the original assertion that only 43 of 59 relevant studies were included."

claim: By applying the C3 Project roles to the CCLs with CHW activities identified in our review, we sought to use a standardized framework to analyze CHW work that can be compared to future CHW studies. new_claim: By applying the C3 Project roles to the CCLs with CHW activities identified in our review, we sought to use a standardized framework to analyze CHW work that can be compared to future CHW studies.Results We identified 3057 records from the databases and 2 records through hand searching

claim:
Results  
We identified 2 records through hand searching and 3057 from databases (see Figure 1)."  
*(Note: This is a direct reordering — not a negation — but it contradicts the original by reversing the source attribution.)*

Wait — this is not a true contradiction. The original claim is not about the *source* being exclusive or primary — it’s about the *method* of identification. To truly contradict it, we must assert that the database records are the *only* source, and hand searching yielded *nothing*. But we cannot invent new numbers.

Therefore, the correct contradiction must preserve the numbers and invert the relationship — e.g., hand searching yielded the *majority*, or databases yielded *none*. But since we cannot invent new numbers, the only plausible contradiction is to reverse the attribution of the two values — making hand searching the primary source and databases the secondary, while preserving the exact numbers.

But that’s still not a logical contradiction — it’s
title: Figure 1.
caption: Flow Diagram of the Literature Review Process for Examining Community-Clinical Linkages with Community Health Workers
new_claim: Results We identified 3057 records from the databases and 2 records through hand searching

claim: Overall, similar to other recent meta-analyses (Sala & Gobet, 2017; Soveri, Antfolk, Karlsson, Salo, & Laine, 2017), we found that training produced benefits to working memory tasks not only similar to the training materials but also to other outcomes (Figure 1).
title: Figure 1.
caption: Effect sizes from Melby-Lervåg et al. (2016) meta-analysis comparing various forms of working memory training versus active control groups. Outcomes shown in blue reflect pretest/posttest measures that are similar to that training materials in methodology and/or stimulus type (near transfer), while outcomes shown in red reflect measures that are different from training content (far transfer). Error bars indicate 95% confidence intervals. Numeric values under each outcome represent the number of different comparisons included in the calculation of that outcome’s effect size.
new_claim: Overall, similar to other recent meta-analyses, we found that training produced benefits to working memory tasks similar to the training materials, but not to other outcomes (Figure 1).

claim: Figure 1 does not illustrate this, despite being a toy simulation of a set of studies testing a difference between means from two conditions.
title: Figure 1.
caption: The impact of publication bias demonstrated with plots of cumulative log odds in favour of true versus null effect over a series of experiments. The log odds for each experiment can be computed with knowledge of alpha (.05) and power (.8); 1 denotes an experiment with significant difference between means, and 0, a null result. The starting point is zero, indicating that we assume a 50:50 chance of a true effect. For each significant result, the log odds of it coming from a true effect versus a null effect is log(.8/.05) = 2.77. For a null result, the log odds is log (.2/.95) = −1.55. The selected set of studies in panel (a) concludes with a log odds greater than 3, indicating that the likelihood of a true effect is 20 times greater than a null effect. However, panel (b), which includes additional null results (labelled in grey), leads to the opposite conclusion.
new_claim: Figure 1 illustrates this with a toy simulation of a set of studies testing a difference between means from two conditions.

claim: When dealing with probabilistic phenomena, a frequentist approach makes more sense, whereby we consider the accumulated evidence to determine the relative likelihood of one hypothesis over another (as illustrated in Figure 1).
title: Figure 1.
caption: The impact of publication bias demonstrated with plots of cumulative log odds in favour of true versus null effect over a series of experiments. The log odds for each experiment can be computed with knowledge of alpha (.05) and power (.8); 1 denotes an experiment with significant difference between means, and 0, a null result. The starting point is zero, indicating that we assume a 50:50 chance of a true effect. For each significant result, the log odds of it coming from a true effect versus a null effect is log(.8/.05) = 2.77. For a null result, the log odds is log (.2/.95) = −1.55. The selected set of studies in panel (a) concludes with a log odds greater than 3, indicating that the likelihood of a true effect is 20 times greater than a null effect. However, panel (b), which includes additional null results (labelled in grey), leads to the opposite conclusion.
new_claim: When dealing with probabilistic phenomena, a Bayesian approach makes more sense, whereby we consider the accumulated evidence to determine the relative likelihood of one hypothesis over another

claim: No further evidence of the cumulative impact of citation bias is shown in Figure 4, which uses studies of intervention for depression.
title: Figure 4.
caption:
The cumulative impact of reporting and citation biases on the evidence base for antidepressants. (a) Displays the initial, complete cohort of trials that were recorded in a registry, while (b) through (e) show the cumulative effect of biases. Each circle indicates a trial, while the colour indicates whether results were positive or negative or were reported to give a misleadingly positive impression(spin). Circles connected by a grey line indicate trials from the same publication. The progression from (a) to (b) shows that nearly all the positive trials but only half of those with null results were published, and reporting of null studies showed (c) bias or (d) spin in what was reported. In (e), the size of the circle indicates the (relative) number of citations received by that category of studies.
Source. Reprinted with permission from De Vries et al. (2018).
new_claim: Further evidence of the cumulative impact of citation bias is shown in Figure 4, which uses studies of intervention for depression.

claim:
**  
The study aims are not to (1) describe the nutrition-related messages shared by transgender individuals through the video platform YouTube and not to (2) suggest the nutrition-related topics that are of greatest importance to the transgender community.
title: FIG. 1.
caption: Sample selection of nutrition-related video blogs by transgender individuals through YouTube. Nutrition-related messages were transcribed and analyzed using the constant comparative method by two authors, separately.
new_claim: The study aims are to describe the nutrition-related messages shared by transgender individuals through the video platform YouTube and suggest the nutrition-related topics that are of greatest importance to the transgender community.Materials and Methods Study design This ethnography is organized and reported according to the American Psychological Association Journal Article Reporting Standards. Ethnographic methodology within nutrition and dietetics research provides valuable insight on complex health issues and health inequalities. A netnography is a virtual or online ethnography that utilizes computer-mediated communications as the data source. Online video blogs (vlogs) were chosen as the data source given their expression of one's lived experience and the potential to amplify the voices of the transgender community. The underlying hermeneutical perspective was extended from its traditional application with written narratives to a modern application with verbal narratives that were recorded and self-published by individuals on the public domain, YouTube.Sampling and data collection A YouTube search (July 5, 2018) was used to identify relevant vlogs using the search terms “transgender,” AND “diet” OR “nutrition”.

claim: Using the same provided MATLAB script program, each data set cannot be reliably analyzed, and the CFA data, including the quantified collagen fiber orientation angle θfiber and the degree of optical anisotropy (DOA), cannot be visualized (bovine tendon: Fig. 1, MVAL-1: Fig. 2, MVAL-2: Fig. 3).
title: Fig. 1.
caption: CFA quantifications for the bovine tendon specimen: (a) an experimental photo showing the longitudinal tendon axis of ∼52°, (b) DC intensity versus polarizer angle plots for the selected 3 × 3 grid pixel points, (see red dots in (a)). The angle corresponding to the peak intensity, indicated by the red dashed line, is the quantified fiber orientation angle θfiber. Colormaps of (c) θfiber and (d) DOA at different longitudinal strain levels.
new_claim: By using the same provided MATLB script program, each data set can be analyzed, and the CFA data, including the quantified collagen fiber orientation angle θfiber and the degree of optical anisotropy (DOA), can also be visualized.

claim:
Tissue dissection and preparation  
For tendon tissue preparation, the central region of bovine tendon was excised into thin tissue sample (width=15 mm, length=40 mm, thickness=1.25 mm), with no effort taken to exclude the synovial sheath membrane enclosing the tendon and without regard to aligning the strip length direction with the native tendon axis (Fig. 1a).
title: Fig. 1.
caption: CFA quantifications for the bovine tendon specimen: (a) an experimental photo showing the longitudinal tendon axis of ∼52°, (b) DC intensity versus polarizer angle plots for the selected 3 × 3 grid pixel points, (see red dots in (a)). The angle corresponding to the peak intensity, indicated by the red dashed line, is the quantified fiber orientation angle θfiber. Colormaps of (c) θfiber and (d) DOA at different longitudinal strain levels.
new_claim: Tissue dissection and preparation For tendon tissue preparation, the central region of bovine tendon was excised into thin tissue sample (width=15 mm, length=40 mm, thickness=1.25 mm), with care taken to exclude the synovial sheath membrane enclosing the tendon and align the strip length direction with the native tendon axis
